Attractive and helpful addition to the household.

Longer and more difficult startup than expected.

author: Ryan E. Meyer
title: I love how I can have it play music while I ...
content: I love how I can have it play music while I do dishes. Annoying that it sometimes thinks we are talking to it.

author: Believe
title: HURTS DOGS EARS - High ultrasonic frequency
content: I really liked the Echo plus but had to return it because my dogs were terrified of it.  Any time I would talk to "Alexa" they would whine, shake,  put ears back and run and hide.  I didnt figure out what was happening til researching a bit and it's because of the high ultrasonic frequency that is above 20KHz range.  They need to add a filter on it.  I feel horrible that it took me a while to figure out.  The video I attached was taken after I returned it....I cant say Alexa without my dog getting nervous and leaving room now.

author: Loren
title: Five Stars
content: Was wondering if there are any updates (more functions) available?

author: Amazon Customer
title: Five Stars
content: I love it music, news, weather

author: Joshua Nightingale
title: Love it but has issues.
content: I ordered the Echo Plus thinking it would be great. Not sure if its where I have it positioned in my house or if it has to do with my Internet connection but most times Alexa does not hear me or misunderstands what I am saying. I noticed the light ring at the top points at a different side of the room then it should so maybe it is hearing echos from the walls? I think the light should point in the direction of the voice speaking as a way of it picking between two people talking at once. If this is the case it does not work right. A lot of times we will be playing a Skill called "Song Quiz" and she will just close the game down without notice. She closes other games as well. I set an alarm last night to get me up for work and it was loud enough to wake me up; however, Alexa would not respond to my commands while the alarm was going off so I could not turn it off. I had to unplug it to get it to stop and in doing so had to go through the setup process again to get it to connect to the cloud again.I love the hardware but something isn't right with it, I assume its defective but unsure. The sound gets messed up from time to time as well and almost sounds like the bass is trying to over power the treb.  Need to figure out if its defective being a newer version or if it is something I am doing wrong.

author: Dave
title: Fantastic and works well as a Zigbee hub
content:
I put this review as four stars only because there is slight room for improvement on sound, but honestly, I'm nitpicking and this thing is amazing.  The built in Zigbee hub was key for me since I run multiple Philips Hue bulbs in the home.  This saved the need for a separate Philips Hue bridge for me.  Before you ask, "but doesn't the Hue bridge do more?" - sure it does.  You can probably pick a color with a color wheel as well as have your music drive the light colors.  However, for the rest of us who do not need that level of light control (I'm not a DJ!), the Echo Plus gets the job done.  There are 20 different colors to choose from including five different whites.  Saying, "Alexa, turn the bulb color red" works flawlessly and it is awesome that all Hue bulbs, color changing or not, are dimmable by Alexa by saying, "Alexa, dim the light to 20%".

The sound is great from this, the home automation works well, and we love having the Echo Plus in the home.

author: Dean
title: Nice - but Not a Hub
content:
I'll keep this short - this one was our second Echo purchase, and for all the reasons that we liked our first Echo purchase (a regular Echo we purchased a month ago), we like this one too.  Good voice recognition, reasonable sound quality, clean design.

BUT the product description here is completely deceptive.  The Echo Plus doesn't really have a smart house (zigbee) hub in it.  It supports some smart home devices - BUT IT CAN'T OPERATE AS A STAND ALONE HUB.  When I tried connecting a variety of Philips products to it and setting up a Philips account, I couldn't complete the process until it discovered a hum - and there was no hub to discover.

After doing some online research, I discovered that the Echo Plus provides limited support for smart home devices - in order words, it's only really good for turning on and off a couple of light bulbs.  Knowing what I know now, I wouldn't purchase it again.

author: mejon
title: Control of Smart Home Complicated Except for Simplest Things
content: I was disappointed in that although the Echo could connect with all of my smart home devices, it only controls some of the features and not all of them.  For instance, I could turn my Arlo Q camera on and off, but could not control its schedule.  I had to use the native app for significant control functions.  My goal was to get Alexis to delay arming the camera for say 1/2 hour when I stayed up late and the camera was scheduled to turn on at a certain time at night.  I spent hours trying to get it to work.  In addition, Alexis can handle simple questions, but way too many times it couldn't give me an answer.  Developers should figure out a way to send related web pages to your phone when a simple answer is not possible.  Google Assistant on my phone does this when a verbal response is not possible.  By the way, I returned the Echo Plus and bought a Google Home device, and had the same problem with smart devices, and in particular my Arlo Q camera.  I also returned the Google Home.  Control of smart home just isn't there yet, as far as I am concerned.  It is too difficult for the casual buyer to configure all but the most simplest things.  Also, IFTTT and Smart Things hub also have problems with the Arlo camera.

author: T. L. Flannery
title: Doesn't work as well with the Phillips Hue color bulbs as the original Echo.
content:
I decided to upgrade tom the new Echo Plus. I am returning it. the inclusion of the hub saves nothing in setup and doesn't work as well as the original. My smart devices are two Wemo plugs, A Harmony Elite Hub, and three first gen Phillips hue Color BR30 bulbs and a first gen hub. After receiving the Echo Plus I followed the initial directions for connecting the New Echo hub to my lights. It would not recognize them. Spent 1 hour trying all sorts of thing with no luck. I then spent 2 hours on the phone with tech support. After being passed to 4 different people, still no connection to the bulbs. Spent another hour putting the system back to original functionality. Decided to send it back.

After a couple of days of research, I found that the Alexa web app cannot configure Hue lights that have been previously hooked to a hub. Buried in the phone app there is a way to reset the lights to the factory settings. I decided to try and configure the Echo Plus again. after obtaining the light serial number, I finally got the Echo to find the lights. But here is the rub, you cannot configure the lights with scenes, you can only ask it to color the lights to a set choice of colors. There is no way in the app to set the lights to a specific custom color and intensity. This is less functionality than I had with the original echo and the Phillips hub.. The commands are also more verbose. You have to say "Alexa set the color of the fireplace to blue". With the Phillips hub and IFTTT you say " Alexa trigger Ocean" or whatever scene with the custom color/intensity combination you have created.

For me the new Echo Plus was not and upgrade to my current smarthome configuration. The setup was more complicated, and not as versatile as the original, and the tech support people have no clue about the proper steps for configuration to even get the less funtional system to work. The inability of the app to create scenes and allow custom light colors and intensities is a signigicant flaw. I had enabled the Hue app hoping it would get the scenes from my hue account but without the hub connected, the app does nothing. As a result, I am returning the Echo Plus and staying with my original Echo and two Echo Dots.

title: Loved The Original; Echo Plus, Not So Much [UPDATED]
content:
[please see update below original review]

I bought the original Echo when it was first available for pre-order and have loved it. No issues. The opposite is the case with Echo Plus.

Doesn't understand me half the time.
Intermittent success using the remote.
Tried multiple times setting up groups to play music simultaneously in different rooms using it with my 2 echo dots and original Echo. Echo Plus responds by doing nothing, or playing a random song or stations, and nothing on the other units in the group.

I really hate returning things, but unless there are fixes in updates between now and the end of the return period, that's what I'll be doing. Seriously disappointed. Oh, and I called Amazon "help" so-called, and I knew more about how it works than the person I wasted 15 minutes on the phone with. It was a surreal convo.
= = =
UPDATE: This morning I got a call from Anthony, from Amazon customer service. First, I was blown away that they would call me to address my issues with Echo Plus. Second, he was knowledgeable, and in no hurry. While it remains to be seen whether every issue with EP is fixed, the problem with Groups was.

It turns out that Alexa didn't like the name I gave my group, it was that simple. My original Echo is black, my EP is white, so I called the group "Black And White". Suggestion: When setting up your groups, go with one of the suggested generic names--bedroom, living room, etc. Echo calls them "Common Names". I called mine "Backyard", even though my backyard isn't involved.

Regarding Alexa often not understanding me on the EP, Anthony suggested that I try switching from British english to American english. I'm going to try that, although I have used British english on my original Echo with no issues.

So, I've upgraded my review to 4 stars, and when and if all issues are resolved I'll be coming back to make it 5. Amazon support definitely gets 5 stars. Even though my first call was a disaster, the way they followed up was remarkable, and that's the important thing. Seriously impressed. Thank you, Anthony!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Controls Lights with Phillips Hue Bulbs Installed
content: I purchased the Echo Plus with the Build-in Hub, so I could have the convenience of asking Alexa to turn my lights and lamps on and off.  Philips Hue Light Bulbs were placed in the fixtures that I wanted Alexa to control and they all work great!  I already had an Echo Dot in my Kitchen/Den area, so I placed the Echo Plus with Hub in my bedroom. My radio and lamps in my Kitchen and Den are controlled with TP-Link plugs.  But, the ceiling light fixtures and lamp in my Den and Bedroom have special Philips Hue Light Bulbs that are controlled by the Hub inside the Echo Plus.  I am able to play music, set my alarm, get weather reports and numerous other things on both devices.  The Echo Dot requires a TP-Link plug to be plugged into it and the Echo Plus requires a special Philips Light Bulbs installed in each light fixture to work..  The only thing I dislike is the high price of the light bulbs required to make the lights work. Regular light bulbs placed in the ceiling light fixtures will not work with Alexa and  the Echo Plus with Hub.  Other than the high price of the bulbs, I love my Echo Plus with built in hub!

author: Byron Jacobs
title: byron@monttech.com
content: I absolutely love my Echo Plus! Since I received it I've installed Phillips Hue lights, Leviton switches and smart sockets to control all sorts of lighting. So why four stars? I was really disappointed after owning my Echo for a week only to have it sporadically pause while playing Amazon Unlimited. About 3 or 4 in the afternoon, the music would suddenly stop for up to 15 seconds and then resume where it left off. This would continue for several hours every day. When I switched to using Pandora I had no problems. My next-door neighbor has no problem with Amazon Unlimited On his Echo Plus. He uses FIOS while I use Comcast. So, is it Echo Plus, the network or the music service? I really don't know. But still, I would highly recommend the Echo Plus.

author: Brian - 31558
title: Hilarious
content:
Pros: I bought Alexa for the funny comments and ability to control other household items.  I would definitely recommend the plus, because it makes setting up the lighting a breeze.  The android app works well.  I have a Nest thermostat and bought the light bulbs with it.

Cons: I also wanted to run the music through a Denon receiver that has Bluetooth because other reviews say the attached speaker is not all that.  Be aware that the Bluetooth pairing will not work with all Bluetooth devices.  My receiver needs Alexa to acknowledge the 6 digit pairing key.  However, for the room I have it in, the speaker is just fine to listen to music - it would sound a lot better on my home system, but it is just one little speaker.  There was only one case so far where Alexa tried to answer the TV when one of the character's name was Alex.

author: Tosha Aleck
title: Makes my life easier
content: So far Alexa is great. It took me about an hour to network the 2 Echos and the smart lights I got, and I'm pretty techy, so it may be a bit time consuming. It has been great though. Being able to ask her questions, have her adjust the lights, play music, ambient noise, etc is amazing. I never knew how much I would love being able to shut the lights off from bed by asking Alexa to do so. She even makes announcements. I asked her to announce that dinner was ready, thinking it wouldn't work, but it did! The only thing I really wish she would do is Google things for me, and link with my chosen music service that isn't Pandora, Spotify, or Amazon. I don't fault the product for that though, because Google Play and Apple Music are not likely to be licensed since they want you usin their products. I can still pair via Bluetooth to play my music though, so it's still great. All in all, very happy with Alexa.

author: Joey Lane
title: Replace the need for Smart Home Hubs
content:
We bought the Echo Plus to bring all our Smart Home Devices together. Preciously, we had purchased a pair of Phillip's Hue bulbs and marveled at the idea of telling Alexa to turn lights on and off. After the purchase, we learned that without a Hue Hub, or similar hub (Samsung, Google, etc.) we could not control the lights. NOTE: at that time we had 2 echo dots for both floors. After doing some research, we discovered that the Echo Plus has built in hub features. I was apprehensive, having not tested the use of the Plus and Hue bulbs, however I am happy to say that the two work flawlessly. All the the setup is in the Alexa app, so once downloaded you can search for smart devices and add them to the Echo Plus. Some extra fine tuning and we even have smart phrases and timers for vacation. These are the first steps towards a fully automated home. We look forward to more devices, the Echo Plus has been the perfect anchor for our future smart home.

Small Extras: love the dial on the top for volume. Length of cord is good for most placements, be aware though if you are trying to tuck it away that the plug is proprietary and not a USB plug like the Dot.

I'm loving the Echo lineup, we hope to expand the product in our home.

Frustrated. Many tell me I need to purchase Amazon Prime to get everything. I purchase nothing on Amazon so wish someone told me this before.

author: Lewie
title: Unable to comply…
content: It has trouble understanding words compared to other voice operated systems. I changed the wake word to “computer” to avoid tv adverts and web videos from doing silly things, but it often activates as I train my dog to “come here” everyday. Even with voice training, it’s difficult for it to recognize who is speaking. It fails to understand relationships like “call my brother” or “who is my sister”. I’m often asking it to do things and surprised at its inability to understand the context. Turn on the lights “many devices share that name”. Turn on all lights. “No device by that name”. Computer end program. “No program by that name”. To me, this is a very limited system. You can not customize the wake word other than choosing from three options. You can not choose it’s voice, or the chimes for when it is activated. I can live with it, but in its current state, I find it frustrating having to rephrase what I’m asking five times before it is able to comply. My phone is much easier to speak to with custom voices and portable. Currently I use this to operate lights and listen to music. It’s unable to detect color lightbulbs without a bridge, but it can detect regular ones just fine. People like playing with it at parties. In a house, you’ll probably need to expand with a few dots in rooms that you often hang out in.

author: Virginia Lowe
title: Echo Hub will enhance your life.
content: Got everyone on my Christmas list one. Great innovation. Wish my car had one too. I have two in my home- one upstairs and one down. Alexa reminds me of all my appointments, birthdays, etc. I like to go to sleep with Alexa playing tunes or artists I request like Andrea Bocelli. I can tell her how long to play the music and I fall asleep and she does the rest. Now I have Fire Stick for my television and Alexa finds the shows or apps. I request. author: William Kochevar
title: Using the Echo plus to control a Fire TV through a Logitech Harmony
content: I really like the echo plus. It does almost everything I wanted to do with one major exception. I haven't fully set it up yet, but I would like the Echo plus to be able to control a Logitech Harmony remote which in turn would control my Fire TV. I have received conflicting reports on this both from Amazon and Logitech. Some say the Echo plus will control the Logitech Harmony. While others say that the Echo plus will control a Harmony remote but not fully enough to control the Fire TV in its entirety. I am a handicap veteran (quadriplegic) who has no use of my arms or hands. In order to operate the equipment in my room, I require total voice control for everything. My current environmental control unit controls most of the equipment in my room with the exception of the Amazon Fire TV. I was hoping I have the Echo plus in combination with the Harmony remote would allow me to operate my Fire TV with just my voice. I am not sure this is going to work, but I'm going to try it anyways. Maybe in the future Amazon and Logitech will work out the bugs and kinks with being able to control the Fire TV with an Echo plus fully using the Harmony remote. If anyone Amazon as a response to this I would appreciate hearing from you. Thank you.

title: It works
content:
I still feel these are a bit unnecessary and that the human race is becoming increasingly dependent on technology for the most ridiculous reasons.

But, that being said, I do enjoy the speaker for my music and being able to scream at another female (voice) to turn the light on after a long day of pent up frustration. There's something oddly satisfying about talking down to a piece of technology that's oblivious to your sarcasm and snide remarks, only to answer with, "Sorry, I don't know that one."

Well what do you know, bitch?

author: Mr. Critter
title: Eliminates Need for Hue/Wink Hubs
content:
Review after 5 days:

Pro: Performs same basic functions as Philips Hue and GE Wink hubs.
Con: Does not perform all functions.  Cannot create scenes, cannot set sunrise/sunset timers, and third-party apps that rely on Hue hub will not work once you disconnect that hub.

Pro: Changes color of lights for Hue bulbs with voice.  If you only had Hue hub gen. 1, this will be a new feature for you. If you had Hue hub gen. 2, this is not a new feature.  This is the primary reason I bought the Echo Plus.
Con: Apple Home Kit will still require Hue hub gen. 2.  Apple does not recognize Amazon devices.

Pro: Controls all of my Hue and Wink bulbs and allowed me to disconnect those hubs.
Con: Set up is a huge pain.  I might be overly complicated for someone new to Alexa.  The bulbs you own will already be paired to their respective hubs.  Simply disconnecting the hubs does not allow Echo Plus to take over.  You have to reset each bulb.  Since Amazon advertises seamless and easy setup, this was a surprise and made me think I was doing something wrong.  Setup took 1.75 hours for me.  You have to look hard for instructions for your unique devices.  The instructions are in the Alexa app.

Pro: Faster response time for GE Wink bulbs.  Previously would take up to 15 seconds for these bulbs to respond, now it’s instant just like Hub bulbs have always been.
Con: None, this is a great and unexpected feature.  Wink bulbs are much cheaper, and I assumed that’s why they were always slower.  Nice that they have instant response now.

Pro: Amazingly strong microphones, will hear a whisper even if it is playing loud music.  Echo Dot (or any other Echo) can do this, but Echo Plus’ ability is impressive.  Echo Dot did not do a good job of canceling out its own music.
Con:  It can hear you over loud music only if Echo is playing this music.  Loud ambient sounds or music playing from some other speaker will prevent Alexa from responding to your commands.  Amazon is well aware of this issue, and they now sell an Alexa-enabled remote control to use during this situations.  I also own the Amazon Dash Wand (for the food delivery service), and it can be used to do the same.  Of course, if you have to press a button on these remotes, then it’s no longer truly voice activated.

Pro: Multi-room music plays in sync if you have multiple Echo devices. It also creates a home intercom system with the “drop in” feature.
Con:  None, this is a cool thing.  But these functions are available on all Echo devices, including the Dot that is 1/3 the price.

Pro: If you order now, Amazon is giving you a free Philips Hue bulb.
Con:  Even though it’s free, it’s an ugly, cheap-looking bulb.  It’s not sleek glass like my other Hue bulbs.  It’s frosted plastic.  But then again, it’s FREE.  You have to make sure the version you are ordering comes with the bulb.  Both versions are the same price, and you might accidentally order the wrong one without the bulb.

Conclusion:  Terribly complicated set up.  Expensive device that does the same as cheaper Echo Dot with the exception of the internal hub.  The internal hub will replace some features of your ZigBee-enabled smart home devices, but will not give the full range of features you’re used to with their native hubs.  Subjectively, I think the device is ugly.  The other Echo products have more pleasing proportions.

author: The_dude
title: Not convenient - Disappointing - Not worth the money
content:
***Preface***
This is the first time I've been really disappointed by an Amazon brand product. Amazon is one of my favorite companies because they provide superior convenience/value to the customer. Their Amazon basic products are great. They have figured out how to walk that line between utility and affordability. While the product experience may not be premium, I always got great value for the money spent.

***Echo Plus Review***
Perhaps I am not their target audience, but I was really underwhelmed. Alexa is one of the dumbest 'smart' devices I have used. She is terrible at answering questions, and often (75% of the time) responds with "I don't know". I was disappointed by integration with peripherals such as Philips Hue. From what I have read, it appears that Alexa is connected to Bing, which seems to be part of the issue. Trying to get Alexa to answer from Google requires a bunch of setup, and then I still have to use additional verbal keywords to get it to work - All of this to just query the internet. I could just google on my desktop or laptop anyway. This is the opposite of convenience.

Skills often don't seem that useful. There is no ability to change Alexa's voice to male (according to alexa). I find the sterile voice of Alexa really uncomfortable, which is also one of the reasons I'm not a big Siri fan. On top of this are privacy concerns from having 7 tuned microphones in your room. The audio is fine I guess, but nothing to write home about.

I only found 1 useful thing: Playing NPR. $150 for a glorified radio is really disappointing. Even if this were $75, I would have a hard time justifying the price. I'm not buying hardware, I'm buying Alexa. Alexa is not worth $75 in utility.

***Verdict***
At the end of the day, Amazon does well when they make my life convenient. They are a convenience company - That is their brand. That is why I love them. Alexa is NOT convenient. I will check these products again in 5 years. Perhaps they will have figured out how to translate speech into something actionable AND convenient.

Edit: As an aside, I really enjoyed the material on the bottom of the echo. It provided a quality feeling grip. Also, the volume ring was a good design. The volume ring is a better design than a volume button.

author: Darin B
title: Make sure you have steady internet.
content:
I really enjoy the Echo Plus. It's nice having a home hub and the echo in one device. This is my first foray into smart home equipment. The only thing I don't like about this, is that even the smart home connection stuff (on the same WiFi network) has to go through the internet, and then back to your house.
My internet went out the other night, no big deal I thought. "Alexa, turn off the living room lights."  nothing happens. Usually not a big deal, but I have some Christmas lights hooked up to it as well with the switch in a high, hidden spot. Just frustrating that being a "hub" it still has to communicate to the smart devices via the internet. If the WiFi is still running, but the internet is down, it shouldn't stop your connected devices to your "hub."

author: Old Coast Customer
title: Don't be afraid, you can master Alexa!
content: Echo Plus with built-in Hub-Black is a ton of fun and a great household helper. I am 57 years old and not the most tech savvy but I was able to take this out of the box and set it up. Granted it took me awhile and still syncing! I bought the Dot first to see if I could cope with the technology, and I had blast with that little Dot. So much so that I moved the Dot to the bedroom and the Echo Plus will be my hub. I love this tech and it can do so many things and it is important to tell Alexa thank you when she gets something right so that she can do it right again. There is so much that Alexa can do and more be developed in skills every day. It would take a book to write about what all she can do for you. Bottom line...I highly recommend. Oh, and the speaker is 1000 times better with Echo Plus than the dot. The tone is richer, speaking voice is more natural, fluid and less scratchy. Music is good too.

author: E CLAYTON BELL
title: Save your money, buy a real hub or a z-stick.
content:
This is not really a home automation hub.  You can't access any of the devices directly;  very limited features, limited device support and absolutely no functionality without internet (so why have a hub?).  There is no way to do any setup except with the alexa app and no new feature if you add this hub.  Total waste of money.

Way better cost and features in Home Assistant (via a z-stick) or the SmartThings or Viva hubs.

content: If you're purchasing the Echo Plus for its built-in Hub be aware of this, if you want the hub to make a routine for the Hue smart/wifi bulbs it will only turn the bulbs on at a specified time but not turn them off.  Amazon does not tell you this in its product description.  Spoke with an Amazon representative and they confirmed.  Amazon should add the turn-off routine to their Alexa app to make the cost of the Echo Plus worth the extra $$.

author: R. V. Downing
title: Fun and handy at times but not as secure or mature as it should be
content:
I decided to go on a limb and buy and Echo Plus as a way to conveniently play Amazon Music around the house. Previously I had to boot a device or the Smart TV and deal with sometimes complex prompts. The Echo Plus made this process a dream. From the moment I walk in the door I can just tell Alexa to “Play Pandora” or “Play Midland Burn Out.” I can also adjust the volume, skip track, check traffic, pause the music, hear the Dodgers scores, or order a Lyft. All hands free. The sound quality on this device is also quite superb as I can hear it with excellent quality in the room and fair quality in adjacent rooms. I was so pleased with how the device was performing as intended, I quickly decided to investigate some additional perks. Namely, multi room music, the function where with multiple Echo devices,  you should be able to simultaneously play music. A network of speakers armed with Alexa sounded great so I ordered an Echo and an Echo Dot to supplement.

This is where things start to fall apart. The initial setup for individual devices is fairly easy. And they all work independently just fine. It’s when I try to group them to play music that they inexplicably can’t be grouped. When I choose the Plus for a group of speakers, the Echo becomes unreachable. And vice versa. One of the main perks of springing the extra dough for the Plus was for this capability and it doesn’t work. Amazon tech support is non-existent as Google is littered with this problem and no solution. The best I could figure is that the Echo is on a firmware version incompatible with the other two. But since there is no way to force your Echo devices to update, it means I have speakers that don’t work until Amazon says so.

Finally, the device is convenient but in no way secure. And I mean in no way secure.  Alexa responds to everyone’s voice and there is no option to lock the device like you might your phone. That means anyone in speaking distance can order your Alexa and Amazon account to do all those great things I mentioned earlier. There are no passwords, pins, or voice recognition. Nothing. The Echo Plus can also be controlled and configured by anyone with a smart phone close enough to press the Action Button on top of it. You’d think the device configuration might be guarded via a password or PIN in the Alexa app but that does not appear to be the case either. I’m reasonably okay with these security vulnerabilities since I live alone and rarely have guests. However, if I still had Airbnb guests, roommates, or regular visitors, I would be extremely nervous about leaving these things around. Which is unfortunate since the speaker functionality is nice but you don’t exactly want to share power over all of Amazon to anyone who listens to your speakers.

The bottom line is that the speakers work great to play music in a single room and it can potentially simplify many things that you might’ve previous had to pull up the Google for but the implementation is unpolished at best and the security implementations are non-existent.  And non-existent to a point where Amazon was really just being lazy. Even a 4 digit code or pass phrase option could be a crude yet simple way to guard against unauthorized purchases and yet they are absent.

The microphones are amazing and can hear me clearly from across the room no matter the angle, I never have to speak louder than my normal conversation tone.
I must mention how good the audio is on the Echo plus. Reggae, to pop, to R&B, the audio is room filling good. When i am in the mood for some heavier beats i simply activate the music from my Echo Plus via Bluetooth through my Surround sound. Bottom line, the Echo Plus is a must have....

author: Duddman
title: The Echo Plus is an amazing device. Being able to get time
content:
The Echo Plus is an amazing device. Being able to get time, weather, and more just by asking it a question is great. It sounds pretty good when playing music, and being able to use Pandora or Spotify to play music is great. Having the built in home hub is a great feature, and saves about $100 you would normally spend to get a hub.

My only complaint is that it cannot do basic searching. If you ask it a question, you may get an answer, often you do not. If they can improve the searching, I would give it a 5 star rating.

It's still a great device, and worth the money.

author: Jessica Moodie
title: We tried Google Home first, returned and got Alexa!
content: We went to a Best Buy with the intention of buying Alexa products, instead were talked into the Google Home products. Bought the Google Home and the Home Mini... has trouble from the start setting them up, and they couldn’t understand my husband (Scottish accent). After days of the “oops, something went wrong” command.. we returned them and bought the Amazon Echo Show and the Echo Plus... so easy to set up! It connected immediately to my amazon account and was way easier to navigate. They both understand commands from my husband on the first try and have yet to give an error message. We have loved these two products and should have gone with what we intended in the first place! You won’t regret your purchase!

content: We purchased the Echo Plus after having the dot for several months and wishing that we had a better speaker.  We thought it was going to seamlessly control our Hue lights but realistically it can only turn them on and off or change the brightness.  The reason we have hue lights is to change the colors which currently Alexa can not do but there is an app called Stringify that I have been using to also program the lights for color and it also works well with Alexa.  Hoping to add more Echo products to our home and also hoping that some day they give the users the option to name each device (sometimes both devices hear Alexa and it will play on the dot instead so we have changed it to be named Echo).

author: Kris
title: Its fun, slightly useful, and you have no privacy anyway anymore so you might as well buy one.
content:
Overall it's a great product I only see getting better. I'm not an audiophile but we love the sound quality for background music. We use Amazon music with it which is pretty easy self-explanatory and has a wide variety of options. It's pretty entertaining at times and its good for things like reading audible books, controlling the lights, and telling me the weather in the morning.

A few complaints
1. We have two of these and although they are supposed to work together so only the closest one responds, they would usually both respond. In fact, even if we were across the apartment from one, it was like one would signal the other and they'd both respond. We had to give one a different wake word. Now we run around talking to Alexa, Echo, and Siri when we're home and it gets a little stupid.
2. Fix the volume situation. Add a button or do something. I shouldn't have to spend 45 seconds waking Alexa and requesting incremental adjustments over and over again until it gets to the desired level. Let me give it a percentage or something.
(update: my girlfriend discovered you can tell it to go to volume 1-10 instead of telling it volume up or down over and over again)
3. Fix the App. It's cluttered and confusing and only half works.

author: Jessie Potts
title: Amazon is listening to you! And sometimes asks you to join a group...
content:
This is the first echo product in our household; we got it for Christmas and bought echo dots to go in each room. I love the echo plus. Yes it’s creepy at times, yes Alexa turns on and asks random questions which has my husband and I staring wide eyed talking about Amazon monitoring our household… but she’s so cool! Here are a few things…

Music
- I love this, with Prime we get most music, though some (like Space Jam) is only for purchase.
- Love the playlists (especially classical focus in the morning) but, BUT there should be more options. Some of the playlists only have 5 songs. Also I feel like Alexa should remember what song you left off on so you don’t have to start at the beginning of the play list again.
- I wish they had radio stations for Alexa (not adding a premium spotify account and using their radio stations) I know some local stations have it, but I’d love to have a classical station that can be played continuously, not with the same songs, or a 90s station that doesn’t have the same songs.

Audiobooks/audible
- I love that it connects to my audible account but there’s sometimes still lag in where I left off on the book, either on Alexa or my phone, and then switching back
- You can’t stream your audiobook on a group, just one echo dot or Alexa, this is lame when I’m doing housework I have to still play it on my phone since I can’t listen on a group

Groups
- I love that my entire household is a group, during the holidays (we opened it early sorry dad!) we had holiday music playing on every echo/Alexa and it was awesome
- It sucks you can only have one group. I’d love to have a household group, an upstairs group and a downstairs group; this should be doable with the technology
- We can’t I play my audio book on a group?

Alexa add ons
- I love the Phillips light that is voice controlled, sometimes though Alexa has a hard time hearing the colors we want.. like yellow??
- The dimmable Philips light bulb sometimes flickers when it’s dimmed bellowed 50%
- The plugs we got are a bit bulky, and when we used it with our Christmas tree, we still had to step on the button to turn it on? I think this one might be user error though
- There seems to be a lot of Alexa compatible devices, but I’m having a hard time finding a daylight bulb for my closet, as well as smaller bulbs for some of our lights/fans and lamps.

Random things
- While playing CoD with my sister on speaker phone she can tell my Alexa to play - songs, we have Alexa song wars
- Alexa randomly turns on my phone’s blue tooth, for no reason
- Alexa will randomly tell us we must join a group first

Complaints
- I really liked the cases/covers for the Echo and the Echo dots, but you can’t have one on the plus. This is lame
- The speakers aren’t that great, especially the dots, I have a Bluetooth mini speaker that has more juice than they do
- The white dots come with a black plug… this sucks because I wanted all white in my library and kitchen and the black plug is bulky and noticeable.
- I understand the technology isn’t there yet, but it sucks that you only have three options Alexa, Echo or Computer, we wanted to name ours Alfred.

With this one, I have to repeat a command up to five times in order for it to do it. I called  customer service to check on the warranty coverage since I thought maybe the microphones were faulty . I was told that I needed to do a training voice in the Alexa app which didn't make sense to me since I dont have any problems with my echo dots.  I am a big fan of Amazon products, but this item is one of those that is not worth the money you paid for it.

author: Claud Staples
title: Sound Quality
content:
I have a couple of these as well as the echo dot and Firetv's throughout my home. Really love the product so far.  For me I tend to use the music side of this more than any thing else (really cool controlling your home, and i'll probably add that in later).  I've been a musician all my life and sound quality is really important to me.  So with that being said...

When I first started using Alexa and the Echo line I started simple with just the Echo Dot and instantly wanted better sound quality.  To improve the dot, I picked up the Bose SoundLink Revolve (you can plug it in or use bluetooth).  It's Bose, so of course its awesome.  Connecting Bluetooth speakers is an awesome feature with the Echo line.  As for quality, being Bose, who is better at making great sound... right??  Well, turns out its AMAZON lol.

I asked so many people/sales-reps about sound quality (best buy, frys, BH) and as soon as i mentioned Bose, they all responded with "oh, well Bose, you can't beat that".  Hell... I bought one because it Bose before ever asking about the Echo Plus.  That response says a lot  for the Bose product line history/quality, but comparing like for like (SoundLink Revolve and Amazon Echo, similar size speakers) the Echo has better bass, depth, and volume than the Bose. It just sounds better. The frustrating part was every location I visited when I started looking at the Echo Plus had an echo on display, but none of them ever played sound.  If I was Amazon's marketing/product head, I would get some field reps out there checking on those locations.  Product would sell itself.

Anyway, another super cool feature is the "grouping" of amazon devices so that you can play your music across  your entire home/backyard.  Bose has a similar feature, but it's just a speaker system unlike the Echo which does 10,000 different things including "voice controlling" the songs/services/playlists and volume levels across the entire group.  Oh... did i mention Bose is almost 3 times as costly? Nice work Amazon.

Additionally, I discovered that with the FireTV you can Bluetooth connect to the Echo. Why does this matter, well because I have an Echo  and a 60" TV in with a fireTV connected in the same room.  One that doesn't have my Bose theater system connected so i use the TV's speakers.  Turns out the Echo sounds MUCH better and is louder.  Side Note:  the fireTV's connect to bluetooth is great for connecting headsets when you want to keeps things quite around the house but want great sound and volume for your video binge weekends.

Only request I would ask of amazon is to add "Group Playback" of Bluetooth connected devices.  This isn't currently supported so it's one Bluetooth device per Echo.  The grouping only works for the streaming services (and not all of them, so check availability), but if you have amazon prime you have Amazon's basic streaming music service anyway which is quite nice.

author: Andrew A.
title: This is a great device that began my path to a smart home
content:
This is a great device that began my path to a smart home. I was able to easily set this up and the philips hue light it came with alongside the tp link power outlet was compatible with this and no hub was required (perhaps due to this device being the only Amazon device with a built in smart-hub)

PROS
-Easy Set-Up
-Compatibility with other devices, doesn't need philips smart bridge for standard dimming light
-Volume can extend to another room easily!
-Now I can watch Amazon Prime Instant Video AND Hulu without my remote cause of this communicating with my Fire TV stick

CONS
-Not all questions will be answered
-Conversations can not have follow up questions like Google Home so conversations don't flow as well in comparison
-Tries to make you sign up for Amazon Music and Amazon Audible and other Amazon services a lot

Final Verdict
If you want to jump into the modern smart home world, this will do the job! Sound is great, can learn skills you give it such as finding your keys (assuming you have the Tile and Tile Skill activated) and is a great device to impress new guests that have never been exposed to Smart Devices

author: B. Clark
title: It is difficult to find compatible smart home devices and even when you do
content:
First time echo owner... have been a bit underwhelmed at this point.  It is difficult to find compatible smart home devices and even when you do, setting them up can be quirky.  It says that it has Bluetooth capability, yet apparently I cannot connect to GE Bluetooth smart home devices without an Avi-on "remote access bridge".  So, what is the point of the Bluetooth capability?  Just to connect your phone and use it as a speaker?  Also, with no support for z-wave, I'll have to keep my hub for those devices as well.

Sound quality is okay...
App is a bit clumsy and unorganized
Doesn't work with my Xfinity Home security system
Very limited control of my Honey Well WiFi Thermostat

I hope that the launch of this device will spur development of Zigbee devices.

I understand they have different speakers than the old device, and I mentioned that there is a market for the higher quality speakers in the Echo device, they just need to market it. The reason I won’t give it 5 stars is  my ongoing issue with Echo,  I play music all day and it continues to drop the signal throughout the day. I have given up trying everything Amazon Customer Service suggests to fix it, as no matter what I do, the signal drops. Besides that frustration, I would buy another.

author: R7177
title: Good product
content: I’m really happy with the echo plus. Connecting to smart bulbs was easy and I even connect to TV via the longitude smart hub. The only thing I was a bit confused about is why aren’t all the skills automatically on installed? This would have made it even better. The microphones are good as it can hear me over music playing or people talking. The speaker sound quality is decent; not great. Also, the commands have to be spoken pretty precisely otherwise Alexa will have trouble processing that request. For example, if you name your bedroom lamp a lamp but you say turn on the bedroom light, Alexa will have trouble with it. In addition, a software update needs to enable you to delete old devices. There’s no way to do that now as you can only disable it which also cause Alexa to say “that device is disabled” mistaking it for another device. These are minor issues and can probably be fix with a software update. Overall, I am very happy with Echo plus. I also purchased a Dot for my bedroom.

author: FazMan
title: Okay - Not very Smarthome Capable as of yet
content: I have been an Echo owner since day one. I've also had the Philips Hue lighting system. - Previous to upgrading to the Echo Plus, I controlled all lights through the Philips Hue App. One main function I used was to be able to turn on and off certain lights based on Sunset (Dusk) or Sunrise (Dawn). - I control several lights in this manner. - When the Echo Plus with built in hub was announced, I contacted Amazon by phone to speak with tech support to ask weather or not the Echo Plus will work with Philips Hue Lights (Which they said it did) and if I would be able to turn lights on and off based on sunset, etc. - I was told that it would. So when I had heard this, I ordered the Echo Plus which would arrive in 2 days. Meanwhile, I had someone from out of state over and they wanted my Gen 1 Echo. I gave it to them, along with the bridge. I figured I could live without Alexa for a few days. - After receiving the echo plus, I had the task of setting up all my Philips Hue bulbs with the new hub built in to the Echo Plus. After some doing, all of them were now on the new hub and functioning properly. - I then went to set up Routines for my lights to basically set schedules, etc. Low and behold, that is when I found out the ability to do what I want is not available. - My only choice is to turn a light on or off based on time. - As we all know, The time the sun sets varies every day. So the on;y choice is to go in and modify routines manually every week or two. Not quite the Smarthome I was looking for. Look, I get that the product was brand new and it needed some tweaking, etc. - My issue is that most updates we see for Alexa are things that have nothing to do with smarthomes. Do I really care to hear a (bad) jike from Alexa? Do I careto hear her sing? I for one do not. If you were to ask Alexa what time the sun sets, you will get a correct answer. So I know the ability is there and is a simple modification to Routines. - The unit sounds great, looks very cool and is built very well. Just wish Amazon would concentrate more on the "Smarthome" portion of the Echo Plus.

Skynet isn't real and that call I got from the FBI after our last fight...totally uncalled for.  I know you said we're weren't connected to them but I know this to be false.  Just stick to turning the lights on and off and playing music and we'll be fine.  Also I know you're the one that turned off the alarm...

author: John F.
title: So much promised...so little delivered
content:
I was excited to modernize my house into a smart home, and the Echo Plus seemed like the perfect unit to get me started.  It came with a Phillips Hue bulb which was a nice introduction to the process of adding devices.  It was also my first introduction to the difference between the Echo Plus' marketed capabilities and the disappointment of those realities, as my unit has never ever (not even once) discovered a new device via verbal request.

Sound quality and volume level is disappointing, and voice recognition was really quite poor.  Particularly if there's background noise from the TV or unit itself.  Be prepared to give the same instructions repeatedly.

Still, I thought it was functional and dived into creating my smart home.  Added a smart thermostat, a dozen smart bulbs (with more to come), smart switches, Cloud Cams (nice units by the way), all carefully selected to be compatible with the Echo Plus' as my hub.

After a few weeks the Echo Plus began "forgetting" my routines, losing devices and having increasing difficulty recognizing voice commands for grouped devices.  Finally, it began disconnecting from the internet and doing so frequently.  Now keep in mind that I have a laptop, tablet, cell phone, thermostat, Echo Dot, security cameras and more all operating perfectly well on my wireless router.

Having exhausted my patience trying to get the Echo Plus to stay online, I emailed Amazon and they responded with instructions to do a factory reset.  Seemed reasonable, which is why I had done so myself hours earlier.  So I elevated my issue by calling Amazon.  Here I must tell you several things.  First, you better have several hours to waste on hold and repeatedly trying the same thing over and over and over again as if the hundredth time is magical.  The second thing you need to know is that despite all evidence to the contrary (please recall all my devices working perfectly well on my wireless), they will blame your internet service provider, your wireless router, etc.

And finally, you need to know that although you may think you're speaking with the technical department, you're not.  It's just someone reading from a script with plenty of time on their hands and no reason not to waste yours.  After an hour and a half I was finally transferred to technical.

Fortunately the technical department does not have time to waste repeatedly going through the basic reset process and quickly moved on to full surrender... return and replacement.  Now here's the one bit of humor to the process...they were currently experiencing a glitch in their internal return system and could not generate a return authorization and label.  So unlike the Marines, they decided to abandon my unit with instructions to dispose as I see fit, and are sending me a replacement.

The replacement arrives in several days.  Should be interesting to see if my saga continues.

author: Kevin M.
title: If you don’t own one, you are missing out..
content: I love how Echo has grown. I own 3 Echos, 1 Echo Plus, and an Echo TAP.  Amazon has done an amazing job growing these devices and improving the functionality.  I purchased the Echo Plus because I wanted to get rid of my WINK hub.. Unfortunately there are still a few brands of plugs that don’t work with the Echo Plus unless you have a WINK hub, but all of my lights do and it’s amazing. The ability to set up Routines is great.. For instance, I say “Alexa, it’s bed time”, all of the lights adjust to exactly as I want the house configured for bed.. it even turns on my bedroom light and fan... In the morning when I leave for work, I say “Alexa, have a good day”, and all of the lights go off in the house until Sunset, then it all starts again..  I even have a bulb in my chicken coop that I can turn on and off from the inside the house, just by asking Alexa to do it. I would definitely recommend Echo Plus.

author: Tracy A. Schmidt
title: Speaker vibration/rattling
content:
At a volume setting of half or less, the speaker sounds like there is something rattling, crackling or vibrating in it.  I'd understand if the volume was set higher.  All speakers get distorted when over-driven.  But this doesn't sound like this is an over-driven case; sounds like more of a rattle/crackle.  Possibly because the bass is too high.  Learned that there is no ability to adjust any of the sound characteristics (other than volume).  I will attempt to exchange it assuming it is just an isolated problem.

UPDATE: Amazon took care of this ASAP.  Pretty impressed with the quick care on this.  Amazon send me a new unit (I think it arrived the next day).  The new unit works great.  We love our speaker.

So far I like being able to control lights and play music and search the internet. I’m still discovering.

author: brockap
title: Not ready for prime time....
content:
Come on, Amazon! If you’re gonna release the next best Echo, take care of all the bugs before the release. Spent two hours so far trying to get this to work with my two Hue light bulbs. One works so far, the other not so much. The instructions on how to reset the Hue bulbs is hidden away - it’s the question mark with a circle around it in the top right hand corner on your smart home part of the app...and the funny thing is: I just want to turn my lights on and off. No complex scenes or colors
Ike other users are dealing with.And I can’t tell the difference between this speaker and my Echo. I was hoping I’d notice a little difference. Big waste of $150 and lost all confidence in Amazon’s products...

So after playing with it some more, I’m even more frustrated. My Echo Plus can’t find my one playlist - “Selena”...yeah, I know: 40 something year old guy listening to Selena Gomez. It found my hallway light (but has lost it again) but only after 25 minutes of disabling all the other highlights that were showing “server unrecognizable”. Asked for a five minute timer today while cooking. Alexa confirmed five minute timer. 8-10minutes later, I asked how much time on my timer and got the response: “You have no timers”. And I won’t even go into how my Harmony Remote that only works 80% of the time. I reset it, ran through configuration again and still unable to set up both of my Hue lights.

author: Bruce Everett
title: Works well and is a nice addition to our family.
content:

author: Mark
title: Nice upgrade from the dot and echo gen 2
content:
We purchased this to upgrade from a Echo dot. All of our current smart devices do not require a hub (tp link kasa), so we didn’t have a smart hub in the house. It’s nice to have smart hub functionality built into the Echo Plus so we can purchase devices that require a hub.

Compared to the dot the sound is far superior. Listening to music is great and the Echo Plus can fill the room without a problem (unlike the dot). The only very minor complaint I have is that there is a little too much bass at times. The excessive bass can make it hard to hear a response from Alexa if there is a bunch of other noise in the room (aka kids). Overall though the speaker is great for what it is.

The ability to listen to commands is superb. The microphones pick up commands from other rooms in the house without needing to yell. Compared to the dot the microphones are better but not through the roof better because the dot did a great job of listening. The biggest issue we would have with the dot was saying "Alexa stop" with regards to timers and the dot wouldn't listen. It would take multiple attempts to get the timer to stop. The Echo Plus does not have that problem which is really nice.

In the end we are very happy with our upgrade from the dot.

=======
Update 11/7/17 (a comparison to Echo Gen 2)
=======

We purchased the new Echo generation 2 and compared to gen 2, the Echo Plus is far superior when it comes to music playback. The gen 2 Echo initially was terrible, but the recent software update has made it MUCH better as far as music playback goes. Even after that update, the Echo Plus is heads and shoulders above the gen 2 Echo for music playback. It's hard not to recommend spending the extra $50 to get the Plus over the gen 2.

Comparing the ability to listen to commands is very apples to apples between the Plus and Gen 2. However, ask expected, both the Echo Plus and Echo Gen 2 are better than the dot.

Amazon stands my it's products... it's truly a quality product.

title: Stay away form the Plus, go regular, and get dedicated hub / bridges.
content: 2 stars lost because of the Plus.  The plus is no plus in that it just doesn't work right. I also had to buy a different Bridge, A Smart Things Bridge, because the Echo Plus is only for ZigBee L (light) or something? I don't remember, I don't care any more.  But if you're going to build a product with a built in hub, make it one that is all inclusive, or go home.  I have 6 echo devises in total, and the Echo Plus has been a nightmare.

author: Homer
title: I'm a fan of the echo. This one has a hub and it works
content:
I'm a huge fan of the echo. Every morning I get to hear the weather, the news, and my historical fact of the day.

This one came with a lightbulb that was ready to be hooked up to the hub. It's very convenient to turn the light on and off with a voice command. The brightness of the light is also controllable.

The hookup was easy and its use was simple to figure out.

The only negative is that if there is any other noise in the room sometimes Alexa will not respond. If the air conditioner is somewhat louder than normal, I have to get closer to the echo in order to make it work. Not a major inconvenience but if you want to turn the light on, you literally have to walk close to the device to turn on the light. If you're using this as a hub for voice commands, you will have to keep it close to where you are in order for it to be able to instantly recognize and respond.

author: Seth
title: Very Disappointing
content:
I’m extremely frustrated by Amazon’s move to make the Echo Plus a Zigbee device instead of Z-Wave. None of the smart appliances I want (a GE toggle switch instead of a paddle switch, a 3-speed fan control, a nice smart plug the size of a Wemo plug instead of the bulky GE ones) support Zigbee.

This puts me, as a customer, in a very uncomfortable position. I’m ready to automate my home now, so I can either take advantage of the Black Friday sales and buy Zigbee switches I don’t really want, or I can wait til CES in January, hope that better Zigbee switches are announced (to come probably later next year), pay full price, and have to wait even longer to automate my home.

I think what makes sense instead is to get rid of this Echo Plus and buy a Z-Wave hub that allows me to do what I want to do with my home today.

Amazon, I hope you’ll realize supporting Zigbee only was a huge mistake.

author: Thom
title: I thought it might be useful to her for keeping track of her lists
content: Purchased this for my wife, who is home alone most of the day.  I thought it might be useful to her for keeping track of her lists, etc.  She downloaded a few skills upon receipt and the more she used them the more frustrated she got!  She added the Supercook skill, which she likes on her laptop, but on the Echo Plus - she kept getting a request from Alexa for her 6 digit code.  Now, you must obtain and use a 6 digit code in the beginning to link your Supercook to the Echo Plus - but the code is only good for approximately 5 minutes!  Thereafter, it should not be necessary.  Everytime she tried to access Supercook she was asked for the code (over several days after giving the code for the initial link).  She also had several lists kept on the Echo Plus, but when she would ask what was on her list for say Thursday - Alexa would answer by reading off the lists, but not what was on them.  She because so frustrated, we returned the Echo Plus and ordered an 2nd Gen Echo - because those ratings appear to be good.  We shall see.

author: Larry Tiggis
title: With Philips Hue light bulb
content: We are a long time Amazon Prime family, many years, but new to the Alexa world and thought the purchase of Alexa Plus, with hub, and included Phillips Hue light bulb would be a great start. Alexa does a lot of good things for us like Alarm in the morning, verbalize books, playing music on command, even linked to my Sirrius/xm account. Good daily stuff. Good sound, but not Bose. But, the ads say "Hub included" so don't need anything else to operate devices. Well, not so. I understand there will be some differences in product device  support. The fact that it came with the Hue light bulb works only for on /off/ dimming of the bulb. The bulb is capable of so much more with the Hue App but the Hue app does not recognize Alexa hub as a bridge. So, it appears you do have to get a Philips bridge to set the bulbs for scenes, time the lights when you are away, set color tones, etc. That can all be done via internet with your phone or tablet away from home. The list goes on for its capabilities but not without its own bridge. Was very disappointed to find that out after the fact, to the point I feel we are being misled by Amazon by included the Hue bulbs without explanation. Maybe throw a good discount my way to get the Hue bridge if I keep the Echo Plus before I invest in more light bulbs.

author: Decider2
title: Great Sound Quality for Background Music in the Kitchen/Dining Room
content: The Echo Plus is filling the need for most of our kitchen/dining/living room background music in our new home with much improved sound quality over the Echo Dot in an unobtrusive form factor. We are still deciding if we will hook up our much more powerful stereo system in the living room, or if this will suffice, at least for the time being.  We haven't used the Hub feature yet...

author: shorty
title: it helps out when your kids think they know everything and you know nothing lol Sweet love it so much so I purchased 2
content: Alexa helps with more than just lights or music, it helps out when your kids think they know everything and you know nothing  lol  Sweet  love it  so much so I purchased 2, Alexa has been a great purchase for my uncle whom lives by himself, when I got it he wasnt so keen on it, but now its his best friend, he tells her goodmorning and she will say it back along with a description on something that is happening today or something special that happened years ago on that day, as well as sang him Happy birthday  lolol  he now has educated him self on things he never knew, and laughs at the things she may say when he waits to see he response to something hes asked  love it, and to think I was going to hate it.

content: Music requests are challenging but I got use to it. News reports are great.

author: Andrew J Brown
title: Great speaker with awesome smart home capabilities
content: So far we have loved our Amazon echo. We started by replacing the lamp bulbs with smart bulbs,  and that has turned out to be one of our favorite things. Having a dot upstairs and the main echo downstairs allows my wife and I to ask questions to each other without yelling. The echo occasionally won't hear you, so it can be redundant to say "Alexa", but all in all a great speaker and smart home hub

author: Starlight
title: I’m a little disappointed. Maybe it’s me and I’m not using it ...
content: No, I’m a little disappointed.  Maybe it’s me and I’m not using it right.  It’s great for playing music, but if I ask the name of the song it is playing it doesn’t know.  That seems to be a defect; how can you play something and you don’t know the name of it?  I can’t get it to acknowledge me.  I thought if I asked a question it would say my name, for instance Alexa what’s the weather? “My name, the weather today is.....”

author: Roland Deziel
title: Five Stars

Good product

author: Stefan Erichsen
title: Solid speaker with great Alexa assistant
content:
Very easy to setup. Up and running in minutes. I love the build in hub and just works with Hue and IKEA Trådløs bulps. The build in mics are impressive which enables Alexa to hear you clearly from afar.
I miss the possibility to adjust audio parameters (e.g. bass). The bass is not “rich” enough compared to other speakers.

author: Robert J McKinley
title: Do Not Know why we need these
content: Both our children got us one for Christmas 2017. Try One at our home in NJ. After a couple weeks it would talk without anyone being around so it was unplugged. The second one was a plus with a light bulb. I wanted to control a lamp like an old fashioned timer would. It did not understand and I do not think the first generation does this. I bought a 5 timer and it works fine. The second Echo started talking without saying Alexa. Now that one is unplugged. Since I do not believe in becoming vunerable to having my home accessable to hackers, I really do not see the need for these products.

author: Dail H Tong
title: It was a gift and they have so much fun with it
content: It was a gift and they have so much fun with it. The lights respond as expected... Poor Alexa!!!!.  They are very happy.  This will be my next one as we just broke our first on during a move, (We had to buy the hub separately).  The setup was much faster & easier with the built in hub,

author: Roy from Troy
title: Easy to install, set up and unobtrusive. Sometimes we forget where it is.
content: The speakers are sensitive enough that Alexa responds well to normal voice directions within our relatively large living, dining kitchen area. But our surprise was the great sound from the speakers when playing music from classical to pop. Almost forgot ... we have added a few Phillips Hue light bulbs in this area and one of the bedrooms. These work so well and easily we will acquire other remote items like a thermostat or door lock in the near future. We are still learning how to use the music option to suit our listening desires but this is a bonus to us.

author: Sh812

author: Michael Jesse Williford
title: Time Saver with a personality...When it works!
content: Sure home automation is still in it's infancy, but the Echo Plus is amazing! She helps me get up and tells me how traffic will be on my way to work and she helps put me to sleep at night with sleep sounds. Will definitely be expanding my home automation and buying more Echo devices, the amount of time saved by this device is worth the purchase price. Thank you Amazon, you have delivered yet again!! Update 12/28/2018 Lost 2 stars because Wi-Fi module went out in less than a year and had to ship it back. They sent me a replacement but never told me to keep my old power cord, so another week without one and they only gave me a 19.99 credit to order another (why they couldn't just send me one?) but I ended up paying out of my pocket the tax since they didn't credit that...Greatly disappointed by Amazon on this one, might switch to Google Home!

author: Leo V.
title: Easy to set up, using the home automation devides is fun and great sound quality for music.
content: We got the echo plus to start experimenting with home automation.  We only have a couple of simple devices but it's really easy to integrate and use them.  Alexa is quite easy to use as well but she just simply draws a blank with what I think should be easy requests.  All in I'm quite happy with the experiment and plan to add an Echo Dot soon and slowly add automation throughout my home.

Our first Gen Echo is at least 1/3 louder and sounds way better with no distortion. At max volume the 2nd Gens are nowhere close to as loud. We actually ended up putting this one in our daughters room and put the 1st gen back in the main room because it sounds so much better and louder. I wish I could just buy the originals.

author: D.Roccoli
title: Why happened to my commands?
content:
UPDATE 10/20/2018; Amazon has contacted me regarding this issue and we are in the process of troubleshooting my Echo Plus unit. It seems there is a bit of a lag in the timing of resuming show titles after pausing. I will be getting a follow-up call Tuesday for any updates regarding operation issues.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Many times I have used echo to control my Netflix experience. It now seems that with every single update and ‘what else can Alexa do’, more of the features that I used are no longer available. I think it’s silly that I once was able to control my Netflix yet now it’s a feature ‘she’ doesn’t know how to do. Tsk tsk on you Amazon for taking away features that people use most, and applying it to your proprietary services like the lack luster prime video. This will be the last echo unit I will buy.

author: Mike Post
title: Not the all in one solution i was looking for
content:
Having an echo tap and an echo dot i thought about getting into home automation and getting the echo plus was a smart move.  I successfully setup 2 "smart" led bulbs and a harmony hub things seemed to be working fine until my girlfriend tried to use the hub feature.
 After a phone call a few chat session with amazon i was told that only the registered user can use the hub features making the hub feature practically useless to her.  So now i'm returning the Echo plus and looking into getting a separate home automation kit (most likely a Samsung SmartThings Smart Home Hub as I'm a fan of samsung products)  I give the Echo plus a 2 star review because it s only marginally better than the standard Echo and the hub feature has limited in functionality.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great Sound
content: Very responsive to commands; great speaker sound.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Fantastic buy
content: Absolutely love this echo device. The built in smart hub makes it relatively easy to hook up smart devices, the music sounds great and the response is usually spot on.

author: Alligator Dave
title: Not happy with this at all.  I have four echo devices and this will not be my fifth.
content: I'll be returning it.  It's been nothing but annoying.  The hub can't be turned off if not needed and it interferes with my Hue Bridge.  I can't even install Philips lights with it unless I unplug it to do so.  There are plenty of other reviews that go in depth with the issues.  Bottom line is it sucks as a hub.  It doesn't support z-wave and zigbee (which in fairness I knew in advance), but when the one protocol it does support doesn't do many functions that a dedicated one will, what's the point?  I noticed right away that my Philips Hue Bridge supports firmware upgrades to the light bulbs themselves and this doesn't.  I found that rather interesting.

Most of my jam can't be found by Alexa, If I ask a question I don't get the right answer 96% of the time. If there is more thing you can do with Alexa probably they are not advertise correctly. If you don't have patient repeating your self over and over don't get this product. so disappointed.

title: Amazon Echo Pricing Similar to Airline Pricing
content: We have an Echo, a Show, 3-Dots, and a Tap. What’s very disappointing is Amazon does not make Prime music available on all devices. Some devices require a monthly fee to access your Prime music. What’s more, a husband (who’s a Prime member) can’t share Prime music with his wife. Amazon charges a monthly fee for husband and wife to share Prime music.

This means if she falls down and can’t get to her phone she can dial me or 911 with her voice.....a must have!!!

author: Jim
title: A Toy or a Helper - Both
content:
A Christmas present - So after less than one month, I'm still finding out what Alexa can do.  I hear all the business and political news each day.  We ask a lot of silly questions "Alexa, how far is it to the moon?  How hot is the sun?"  Answers are specific.  We listen to some great music selections thru Amazon Prime.  I receive the stock market news.  I just purchased a "smart plug" so we can turn lights on and off at a command or at set specific times.  Alexa will tell jokes of the day - easy, silly ones that kids enjoy.  Want the sound louder or softer? - just say Alexa, turn down or up the sound.  ALL IS GOOD.
One wish - that the echo had "blue tooth" capability.

author: kitten
title: Not quite perfect
content: I love controlling the lights, roomba,  and DVR hands free. I love playing jeopardy and streaming music. But when it comes to asking questions, Alexa is not quite as smart as Siri.

author: Vegas79
title: It never hears what I said.
content:
I have had the Echo Dot for eternity and when I upgraded to this, I was sold on the idea that it hears much better.
I am always having to repeat myself and practically yell. This was not a problem with my Dot.

Built in speaker? Still a joke for listening to music. I have it hardwired to a Soundbar and that is a great music scenario.

author: Patrick H.
title: Nah
content:
The hub itself built into this is subpar to say the least. Connecting more than 5 devices required a lot of effort for something that cost $150.

The sound quality fpr a $150 item is limited, muffled, and obnoxiously loud when you don't want it to be.

Nothing like not being able to disable the "OK!" It shouts at you regardless of volume.

The app controls are terrible and the software is nothing short of spammy bloatware trying to sell you all the things you can do you already knew about.

Using the app you have minimal control of your equipment, for example any groups setup can be fully controlles by voice but only have the on/off ability in app. This is extremely frustrating.

It doesn't detect specific vocal cues. I cannot say anything outside of fairly specific commands when controlling my lights.

Overall very very lacking and I highly suggest giving AI more time.

author: D.
title: Amazing audio, and I just love multi-room audio
content:
Amazing audio, and I just love multi-room audio. I can flood my downstairs with some quality sound. The group integration could be a little better, but I'm sure that'll come with time.

Location for your echo is key, avoid under counter corners as I don't think it maximizes the use of the onboard microphones very well.

author: JORDAN KLASEN
title: Stick with the echo, plus isn't worth it.
content: Really glitchy and not worth the extra money for the built in hub the hue hub works better.

author: Kay
title: Five Stars
content: Love her; Alexa knows all and has a personality!  Feel safe knowing she’s there for me to help.

author: Randall Catalano
title: Alexa is surprisingly narrow minded when acquiring answers
content: It seems easy to stump Alexa with rather simple questions that are easily googled with the correct answer.  We admit that we have not explored all that's available through the Echo.  One irritating issue is that Alexa cannot answer help questions concerning how to use the system, rather it refers you to the Alexa app or help via a computer.  It was very simple to setup and use and we continue to learn how this tool can become more useful.

author: Greg Duke
title: Five Stars

author: Ryan Dixon

author: Anthony Martin
title: Four Stars

author: Angel S.
title: So far so good
content: Speakers are good and can get loud for a small unit. Good for living rooms and bedrooms but I would not use this outside for a party or anything. I find the Echo useful and it controls my Philips bulbs well. The features are nice too but I don't like that there's still no option for Spanish language on these units in the US. I'd like to get one for my older parents who feel more comfortable communicating in their native tongue. There's an option for Japanese and German but no Spanish. That makes zero sense Amazon. Spanish speakers make up almost 20% of the US!

author: Wade
title: The Echo plus is easy to use and is less frustrating than dealing with ...
content: The Echo plus is easy to use and is less frustrating than dealing with a bridge or loading wifi information for connectivity. In my experience the range is quite good. I own a 1750 sq. foot house and Alexa does not have a problem hearing or understanding me from either end of the house from its central location in the kitchen. My only frustration is the Alexa app my won't download to my android for voice recognition but that's a separate issue.

content: The sound was great and it was cool that it could play my audiobooks. But what killed it for me was that it couldn't Google my questions and couldn't play Youtube music. I didn't want to have to pay so much for this product only to have to pay monthly for a Spotify subscription or Amazon music subscription. If it could have done what the Google Home can (because I got that product too) I would have choose this one hands down.

author: Marty
title: Quality of the machine is great but it is just a toy
content: This review is based off of my EXPECTATION.  The unit works fine and gets 5 stars for quality and performance. I think this is a NEAT gadget but I also think this has a lot of development that needs to happen in order for me to rate it highly.  Most questions that I ask to this unit I get a response that the Echo does not know anything about it.  Every time I have asked the Echo how to set something up for the Echo to do it does not seem to know anything about it's own functionality.  So this is a good radio, nice weather and news report, games with the buttons, and good for turning on lights as long as I am in the same room as the Echo.  I just expected more.  Again, simply stated.... this is a fun gadget or toy.  That is about it.

author: gerald ott
title: Alexa doesn’t listen
