author: Roxanne
title: I like that I can tell her to turn on and off lights that my husband leaves on. Also I got my mom one and she can have Alexa to
content: Love it

author: Madison vanHaastrecht
title: I was excited for my speaker until it came in and became completely useless too me
content: If you are a college student and live in a dorm or use the college's wifi, DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT. I currently live in a college dorm and the wifi sends you to a page where you must have a student login to use the wifi, this is considered an insecure public wifi to the Amazon Echo therefore I cannot use my speaker. I cannot connect to bluetooth until it is connected to wifi which I just said, it cannot do. Having an iPhone 7 plus, I also do not have a aux cord port. That means that even if I wanted to use it as strictly a speaker, I can't do that either without buying an auxiliary cord and a dongle (the piece used to connect an aux cord the the charging port of an iPhone). I have talked to two online representatives and neither one understood my problem or helped in any way. I was excited for my speaker until it came in and became completely useless too me. I highly do not recommend.

author: John
title: Be patient!!
content: I love the sound very good. We use it for home automation also works well!!

author: Drew
title: Good Choice
content:
I purchased this unit mainly to source as a hub for smart light bulbs. Speaker has great sound, not disappointed at all. Also can adjust temp on nest thermostat, nice.

I liked the echo plus so much, I purchased 2 echo dots and we now use drop in feature, along with smart outlets to power off TV during the night to combat 2 sneaky adolescent boys who love to game. Did homework when deciding on echo plus. I was skeptical especially with the 1 and 2 star reviews.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Luv the echo plus!
content: Luv luv luv!!! The echo plus!  Lots of fun and has an amazing amount of skills to enable using the Alexa app. Have set it up to call other family members Alexa’s which was amazingly easy to do. The ease of use makes it perfect for anyone - no need to be tech savvy to use.

author: sdcaRN
title: Great addition to the family
content: I’m still learning all that Alexa has to offer, but even so I’ve quickly realized that the Echo Plus is more than home management—it’s more like life management for a person that lives life on the go!  Love it!

author: Steven P.
title: Echo Plus has great sound, The Hub controls smart Hue lights and more, also has a 3.5mm stereo output that is attenuated.
content: I Love this Larger Echo plus, I first purchased a echo dot. Right away I decided to return the dot and get the larger unit. This echo plus actually has bass and a great sound. After hearing the difference I went down and purchased another echo plus, now I have one in the living room and one in the dining room, this combination fills the whole house with sound. There is enough power in two echo plus that I don't need to turn it up to fill the whole house evenly. The only drawback is getting the units working in sinc function together took calling a tech at amazon. But they were nice enough to go over it step by step. Now that it's working, I haven't had anymore trouble, even when the house lost power, the system came right back on line. I did try to hook up the audio out put, it has a stereo 3.5mm output that is attenuated, nowhere in the manual is that stated, the tech had to call me back with that info. and left out the fact that if you plug in the stereo 3.5mm plug it shuts down the sound from the echo plus, and the output to the amp is not line out, it's powered like a headphone out.

author: jennifer boucher
title: Five Stars
content: Great!

author: Tamera K.

content: Fun product.

author: Doris
title: Instant music 4me
content: I like it ..getting 2 know it .dislike it didn't come with a battery 2 take on the go ..

author: tj
title: Best Alexa ever made
content: Nothing to dislike I love my new toy that has made my house a smart home.

author: Anthony Delebreau
title: So far so good
content:
I bought this as a gift for my wife.  I've been thrilled with the ease of set up as well as the overall quality of the Echo.  I bought it on sale and it was bundled with a Hue light which was really impressive for me.  The ease of use particularly how you can play single songs, songs by artists, genres, and even albums was really nice.  Other ancillary features like finding easter eggs give it personality.  Sound quality is very good but if you're a speaker aficionado I could see how you might be able to find fault, especially with the bass.

I bought this when it was on sale for $100 and bundled with a light.  That was a great value.  Be sure to keep your eyes open for when this goes on sale.

author: Joe Roth
title: A great product
content: I like that it’s voice activated but it don’t link with any other Bluetooth devices only Alexa devices

author: Gerald Gorfain

author: Robert J. Moore
title: Great Product!
content: Still haven’t learn all the Echo can do, but so far, quite pleased!

author: Al
title: Sounds great and plays well with others
content:
Great sound, easy to use and works well with most products

Other smart devices that have "Skills" listed on Amazon work flawlessly. Older devices used through other hubs such as trying to control ceiling fans through an RF blaster like BOND can some times be quirky and do not allow as much control.

I have an older Harmony Hub that I am still working the bugs out on, but overall the device works great has a beautiful sound.

author: Jose M. Nieves

author: CMiller
title: NEVER WORKED CORRECTLY FROM THE GET-GO!!
content: Would give it a ZERO if I could. Amazon delivered new Echo Plus on Aug 20th. Went on vacation. Returned and finally set up new Echo Plus in October. Never worked correctly right out of the box. It would electrically power itself off after 10-15 seconds or had to constantly touch Action button to wake it up to make it respond. Tried different outlets thinking bad outlet. Called Amazon, connected to tech support. Went thru the troubleshooting motions. They agreed something wrong said to return it for repair and wouldn't replace because it was over 30 days since I purchased it. They returned it 2 weeks later said they reloaded software-all is good. Re-set it up...surprise!...nothing changed. Still powers itself off completely..have to unplug/replug in power adapter off and on... When it stays powered up... which is iffy...you have to press Action button for it to respond otherwise goes to sleep. Left it plugged in for several days without fooling with it. It now fires up in the middle of the night to play Bob Seger music without being asked.  By the way, our house is dark and quiet at night, so nothing to trigger this piece of junk.  I'm basically done with this turkey. Will leave it plugged in for a few more days to see what else it may decide to do on it own if anything and then throw it away and move to a competitors product. JUNK

author: Daniel Swenson
title: Responsive.
content: As advertised.  Connected my smart bulbs with no problems.

author: Jason N.
title: Good stuff!
content: So far so good... already had a Tap and a Dot...  this purchase was to gain the ability to dim/on/off lights in our family room w/o getting up because I'm super lazy....  but also controls all of our holiday lighting via tp-link plugs and works pretty nicely for that as well.  Having it in the kitchen (center of the house) for music has been nice too, the Tap now stays upstairs so we have music on demand everywhere we want :)  Not as big of a step up in audio from the Tap as i'd expected, but it's fine.

author: NCC
title: I am very disappointed.
content: Extremely disappointing. This version is a step down from the original. The volume is much lower when comparing to the original. For example, the first-version Echo I usually have at "volume 4" but the new plus needed "volume 6" for the same sound level. There is no noticeable difference in sound quality. It seems the speech recognition (microphone array) does not function as well as original. This is moving in reverse. I am very disappointed.

author: Linode C
title: Three Stars
content: Forget the advert... you need to shout before Alexa will hear you while playing high volume music.

author: Vidia
title: Alexa is great but the hub isn't
content:
When I got this Echo I was excited to have a device with better sound than my Dot and a hub to control some Hue bulbs.

What I didn't realize and also wasn't fully communicated to me, is that you can't use Hue bulbs to their full potential with this device. You can only turn on and off the lights and set them to a number of preset colors. You also cannot update the bulbs to the newest firmare which is a security concern for me.

Do not buy this if you want a full featured hub for your new IoT devices. If you do, you will end up needing to update to a standalone hub, which makes the hub inside this device redundant and pointless.

I still love the echo and have zero complaints about the Alexa functionality or sound quality of this device. I'm only disappointed with the hub's functionalities.

Paired with my WiFi thermostat first try. Awesome. So much more to learn and add. Thank you amazon.  I love the daily news. Pick from over 3000 different news apps. Not sure why so many bad reviews. I have att internet (30 mb download 10 upload) Normally I don’t write one but felt the need to defend this awesome addition to my home. Got some WiFi plugs showing up soon so I will update. Good luck.

I needed this so I could communicate upstairs to my handicapped wife. I even bought an extra echo dot to do this. Could not get it set up because my smartphone is not compatable. Read some forums and such and this is not a unique problem. In fact I read there are many such problems with a variety of features. None of these were addressed in the product description. In the computer world I call these "yeah buts". Well it can do this and that and this. Well can it? Yeah, but...............

Oops I mean “Alexa turn on the family room lights”. I also never realized I call my couch a sofa some times.  Unfortunately my Alexa is confused by my changing names for where I sit.

Easy to set up and to operate.  The sound quality is excellent and the volume control gets loud enough so that it can be heard throughout the house.

author: Libby Burkhart
title: Great piece of mind.
content: This is one of those products that using it makes you want to use it more. The smart home features and the drop in feature let you stay connected to your entire household. But one thing for me that you never hear about is the hands free messaging. So why is that so important?  I live in a secluded area with no neighbors. If I were to fall in my house and not have my phone around me all I have to do is shout out to Alexa to text my husband or make a call. I am not so old that I need a fallen  and I can’t get up device. But this gives me the security that I need if I were to fall or get injured. Great piece of mind for me.

author: Jake D.
title: Great speaker!
content: So far this echo plus has been fantastic. It came with a single Phillips hue bulb, which is my only "smart" home device. I have given five stars based almost entirely on the fact that, bottom line, it's a great speaker to my ears. I've spent the same amount on speakers that didn't perform as well as the echo plus, and you can talk to it. There's something nice about telling Alexa to play one of your favorite bands, and poof, their playing. Overall, would definitely recommend. Also, should mention that I chose this model because of the built in smart hub. However, I haven't had that much of an opportunity to play around with that aspect. Will update if anything major changes in the future!

author: David T Flynn
title: This is a great item. I have tied in some light control ...
content: This is a great item.  I have tied in some light control accessories and will be getting a wifi thermostat shortly.  Everything ties in well and set up was easy. The sound on this unit is really impressive for such a small device and the microphones have no problem picking up your voice.  If you get multiple units (we have two Dots and a regular Echo) make sure you give each different names unless they are on separate floors.  Otherwise they will all respond when you call it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Sound quality is good for music
content: Sound quality is good for music, that's about it. Smart home functionality is worthless. I invested in smart bulbs for the entire house (mix of Phillips Hue and Cree), set up groups for every room, etc. Everything worked great for a few days. Then bulbs would randomly stop working, giving a "device is unresponsive" error in the app and a "device with that name was not found" error from Alexa. Echo devices will randomly show a red a ring and not respond to any commands a couple times a day. Group and device names stop working requiring me to re-learn every device with a new a name, create new groups with different names, etc. The two lights in my baby's room were originally grouped as "Kristine's room". They stopped working one day saying there was no group or device with that name. So I forgot all devices, reset them all, relearned and renamed them as "baby's room" which worked for a couple days, now neither of those group names will work and the group is called "room 3" which is just frustrating. After a couple hours on the phone with Echo support, they had me running around the house unplugging every echo in every room, then running around holding each action button, then running around resetting all the lights individually, nothing fixed the issue. Their response was that I needed to purchase a Zigbee hub and download the Zigbee app on my phone to control everything. The only reason I purchased this Echo Plus was because it has a built in Zigbee hub so I would not need a bunch of external hubs and multiple apps to run everything. I refuse to purchase another hub, etc. So now I just deal with it, running around the house every couple days spending an hour or two resetting each and every bulb, relearning them all, re grouping them all and testing them. It is much more of a hassle then anything, but I spent so much money on all the Echo devices and bulbs that I refuse to just let them not work.

author: RPL
title: Good...  just good. Not that much better than previous generations
content:
If you already have an Echo, I'm not sure there much, or any reason to upgrade to this new echo.  First, for those people buying this Echo in order to get rid of your current hubs, that may or may not be possible.  If you have a Hue hub, this Echo Plus is not a direct replacement for it.  In addition to bulbs, the Hue hub supports motion sensors, dimmer switches, and tap switches.  It also supports Apple Homekit.  If you deregister your Hue peripherals from the Hue hub, and try and connect them to the Echo Plus, while the bulbs will connect, the motion sensors and dimmer switches will not. Also, you will lose Apple Homekit support.  You will also lose all the automations the Hue hub supports like sunrise to sunset and other automation.  Also, if your internet goes out, your Hue hub will continue to work and you will be able to control your lights with the Hue app.  If your internet goes out, the Echo Plus will not be able to control your lights by voice, or the Alexa app.  Lastly, all the 3rd party Hue apps are designed to work with the Hue bridge, not the Echo Plus.  So, those apps will also not work.

If your current hub is Z-Wave, then the Echo Plus will also not be a direct replacement for it. You will need to keep that hub as well the Echo Plus does not have a Z-Wave radio in it.  If you want to do simple things like turn a ZigBee bulb on and off, and dim it, then the Echo Plus works fine.  If you want to do more complicated scenarios, then you will need to keep, or buy a another hub. Since Zigbee is the only protocol that is supported at this time, you need to look for light bulbs, and some other peripherals, that use that protocol in order for it work with the Echo Plus.  But with that said, there will be some devices that use Zigbee that will still need their manufactures hub to work.  So, again, it will not be as simple as looking for a ZigBee device and expecting it work with the Echo Plus.  Since there is currently no supported list of devices, trial and error is going to be your best bet in trying to figure out which ZigBee devices work with the Echo Plus and which do not.

As for sound, that part if more subjective.  I like a little more base in my music.  The Echo Plus sacrifices bass for treble in this new design.  So, to me, it does not sound as great as the previous Echo.  To me, it sounds a little flat.  My old Echo sounds much richer and fuller than the Plus.  So, if you like your music with more bass, then you might be disappointed here as well.

Apart from the above, the Echo Plus does everything the old Echo does, so I'm not going to repeat everything here as you can read about those features in reviews of the last generation Echo.  The microphones on the Echo Plus seems more sensitive to the previous generation though.  It appears to be able to hear me more, even when the music is turned out loud.  Where the old Echo had issues doing that.  Also, the Plus has a 3.5 mm audio jack.  Therefore, you can more easily connect it to your stereo, external speakers, etc. with a wire, if Bluetooth is not an option.

So, all in all, the Echo Plus is good device, but I don't think it's that much better than the previous generation to warrant an upgrade.  If an upgrade is wanted, then depending on you hub needs, the smaller newer Echo might be the better choice.  If you are new to the smart home arena, then try and figure out what you want your smart home to do, then pick the best system(s) that get you want you want.  Don't assume the Echo Plus will solve all your smart home needs.

title: Great device with built in hub
content:
Great device. Love the functionality and the fact that it has a built in hub.  I am slowly upgrading many of the components in my home to smart devices and this will serve as the hub for those devices.

The one complaint I have is that I have this and several Echo Dots and they are set up to play music as a group.  I can play music on just one of them, or on all of them at the same time throughout the house.  The Dots are connected by bluetooth to better speakers.  If I ask Echo to play music on just one of the Dots connected by bluetooth to better speakers, the music will play through the bluetooth connection.  If I ask Echo to play music through the group, it will only play the music through the built in speakers in the Echo Plus and Dots which are pretty low fidelity.

If I fire up my iPad and look at the settings of each of the Echo devices, they still show active bluetooth connections, they just won't play the music through them.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Great concept but increasing problems with devices.
content:
Five Amazon devices increasingly have problems

I am a 77 year old senior citizen with some disabilities that make it important that I be able to control plugs by voice with my Amazon units.
Three echo devices and two dots have become more and more unreliable. I believe the basic problem is that Amazon has sold so many units that its computers can no longer properly interface with the devices. One of the echo devices is a basic echo, two of the echoes are echo plus units purchased in December 2017, the two echo dots were purchased November 2017, and the basic Amazon echo was purchased July 2017. I have the Alexa app on two android phones. One of the phones is several months old, with the app having been updated relatively recently. The other phone is two days old, and the app was installed on it within the last 48 hours.

Examples of problems

1. Devices are no longer compatible with TP-link Kasa plugs. Yesterday morning the plugs were working fine. Then as the day went on the Alexa devices became unable to control first one of the plugs, then two of the plugs, etc. until it could control none of them.
Here is an example of what happens when I try to turn on a light in my spare bedroom with a voice command. All five of the Alexa devices give the following message:
“Sorry something is wrong. To control the spare bedroom light, try disabling the skill and then re-enabling it from your Alexa app.” Disabling the skill and re-enabling it does not fix the problem. I have the Alexa app on two different android phones.

On both android phones the Alexa app for the nonworking plugs shows a message “Skill is unresponsive.”

 If I attempt to manually turn a plug on or off in the Alexa app, the plug does not go on or off. All that happens on either phone is it I get a message stating that the skill is unresponsive. However, if I go into the Kasa app, I can manually turn the plugs on and off–showing that they are connected to the Wi-Fi network. I tried deleting this skill for one of the plugs and then attempted to re-create the skill. The Amazon app was unable to find the Kasa plug.

I spent a long time today on the phone with an Amazon representative who was unable to fix the problem and is escalating it. He said that someone will call me sometime.

There is no doubt in my mind that the problem lies with Amazon. The Alexa app on two different phones states that skills for the Kasa plugs are unresponsive. I spoke with the technician at Kasa who said the problem is with Amazon.

2. Several months ago all of my echo devices began to occasionally respond to a voice command with a statement such as “I’m having trouble understanding right now, please try again later.” If I repeatedly gave the command, eventually the echo device would understand. I sort of felt like I was trying to make a phone call to a very busy line in which the only way to get through was to repeatedly retry.
3. Accuracy of response by all units has declined. Despite my having trained the units to recognize my voice, they increasingly do not properly understand. Sometimes they reply that “I don’t know that one.” Sometimes they state, “I’m not sure” sometimes they carry out an action that I did not ask for–in other words they respond to a command with an incorrect action.

The basic fact is that five different devices purchased at different times are becoming increasingly unreliable and unusable. Another basic fact is that I was unable to get through to a higher level technician and was told that someone would call me sometime. Amazon should stop selling these devices and work on fixing their computers.

After posting the above review, I tried a chat with Amazon and sent this entire review along with a strong request to speak to a supervisor. I was connected finally with a person who helped me restore all of the skills for the tp-link Kasa plugs. There is still the less pressing problem of all of the devices having increasing problems with recognizing commands correctly. The various echo devices are a great idea, but there are still problems I think with the Amazon computers and their interface with such devices.

author: David Anderson
title: Not compatible with as many devices as advertised
content: I am not a very tech savvy person so this is a review for those of you looking to jump onto the smart home band wagon but don’t have a ton of tech knowledge. I was excited about the echo plus because it seemed to eliminate the need for additional hubs-the middle man between Alexa and smart devices. I felt like I did a lot of research before buying this echo and before buying my smart home devices but apparently I didn’t read the fine print. In the description of the Echo Plus it says that it is compatible with all ZigBee devices and there is a hot link which takes you what I would assume were these ZigBee compatible devices. I bought a Schlage lock and some light switches that were listed on this page but much to my dismay my Echo Plus could NOT discover them no matter what I did. Then I dug deeper into the Alexa app-specifically the skills page and found out that the lock and light switches were in fact NOT compatible with this hub and required a separate $85 smart things hub.  I was very disappointed and felt misled by the initial link to supposedly compatible devices. There is no point in paying the extra money for the PLUS if you are going to need to buy a separate hub anyway. I will likely return mine and just get a standard Echo.

title: It's good but it has one major problem.
content: I've been wanting an echo for a while now. I looked at the reviews for the original echo, echo dot and other echo devices. I decided to hold out and wait for the second generation echo. I was debating on getting the new echo ($100) or the plus. I decided to get the plus since it has a built in hub and it came with a light bulb. When my echo and light bulb arrived I was excited to set them up in my living room and test them out. It is not the best sounding speaker but it does what it is intended to do. The commands get recognized almost all of the time. The commands are kind of limited but it will do. The one major problem I have with it, hence why I gave it two stars, is that it does not connect to the lightbulb that came with the echo! I have tried using the command, the app and even typing the serial number of the lightbulb and nothing. I have read other people's reviews and its the same thing. They are having trouble with the echo connecting to the lightbulb that was included with the echo. What's the point of buying the plus if the built in hub does not work. I think I should have just gotten the regular echo and saved the $50.

author: getsomesleep
title: Why didn't I buy this earlier?
content:
Incredible piece of technology.
I have this right center of my living room on an island kitchen counter. The mic and speaker goes in every direction and the quality of the sound is quite good. I connected the Echo via Bluetooth to my Sony soundbar on my TV but find the Echo placement and 360 sound more appealing. It's no audiophile equipment but there is good range and decent bass. The sound is more than adequate for any indoor entertaining and loud enough to bother neighbors in my building. The knob on the top works great for adjusting volume. This is my first Echo device and I would imagine having to press volume buttons (on the Echo 2) a large inconvenience and not as precise. For that alone I would recommend this over the regular Echo (2nd generation).

The piece looks quality and is quite sturdy with some weight on it. The rubber material on the bottom has a good grip on the granite counter-- my cat can even rub her scent on it without tipping it over.

This order came with a free Philips Hue Bulb which I installed along with an extra one I bought. I put the 2 bulbs into my living room floor lamp, turned on the light, and all I had to do was say "Alexa, connect my devices". The default names for each bulb was assigned as "First light" and "Second light", so I can have a dimmer floor lamp if I just turned on/off one of the lights by saying "Alexa, turn off the second light". In the Alexa app, I created a 'Group' with "First light" and "Second light" and named the group "The light", so to turn on the lamp with both bulbs shining I just say "Alexa, turn on The light".

I was surprised how easily the bulbs connected to the Echo Plus with its built in hub. I thought I would have to buy a hub bridge to connect to my floor lamp power plug. Apparently there is some technology built directly inside the bulb! I was surprised by that. Awesome.

You will feel like Tony Stark on this device. I added quite a few "Skills" like 'Thunderstorm sounds' and 'Quote of the day' . Alexa always loads them up quickly. Adding songs that you hear to specific playlists on Amazon Music is also a great feature.

I can go on and on and this is only my second day of ownership.

I was lucky to buy this for $100 on Prime Day, but I think for $150 is it pretty expensive considering the Echo 2 is only $100. In my opinion, you will be paying a premium for the Echo Plus and you have to decide if the value is there for you:
1) Taller and 360 sound unit.
2) Volume knob on top that you spin (I think this is a huge benefit over buttons)
3) Built in hub for Hue bulbs. After researching more, there are some cons to this setup if you plan on having more advanced light setups. For me and my floor lamp, it's just perfect.

I highly recommend it and will buy an Echo dot for my bedroom now.

title: Good Unit But Only If The Accessories Are Purchased
content:
I like the appearance of the unit and the sensitivity of the microphone.
The setup was another story.  I found the instructions resulted in me, the user, making assumptions about what was to be done, and it seemed that all my choices were incorrect.  This led to an install that should have taken 10-20 minutes, took me two days.
I have worked on computers and accessories for over twenty years, so I am not a novice when it comes to installations of equipment.
I also discovered that without all the accessories (which are quite costly), the Echo is only a glorified Siri box.
Once I have the funds to buy the accessories that control the devices that Alexa can turn on and off, etc., I might be more excited about the product.

author: Earth Spirits
title: Give it Some Time
content:
I have an original Echo gen 1 that has been working fine for a couple of years now. I am not sure why some people are saying that the audio is worse. I think it is better and most certainly better than the Echo Dot.
The microphone also seems more sensitive and better able to pickup your voice even while it is playing music loudly.

I got this to see if it could be an all in one solution as I currently am also running a Wink Hub 2. I wanted to see if I could just use Alexa and the Alexa app on my iPhone to control everything in the house which includes bulbs, door locks, egg minder (yes I do use it for keeping up with our own chickens eggs and which are the freshest ones). I want to set up scenes and schedules to automate more lights. So far I haven't yet got it to be an all in one. Alexa did not detect any of devices on the Wink Hub. I think there will be more than just asking Alexa to "discover new devices".

With Wink now offering home security monitoring at a low rate things are really evolving in the smart home market. There are so many companies vying for the space. Nest also has a new security system out. Ring doorbell, all the major door lock companies, thermostats, lights, etc... I really think it will be between the big players to see who wins out for me. Apple with Homekit, Amazon with Alex or Google. So far I think Amazon is far ahead of the competition. I think this echo plus just needs some time to really shine. Give it a few software updates and it's upgraded features will be more clear and present.

I am going to keep playing with this Echo Plus. I think it will prove to be a good upgrade in time.

author: Ryan Tremblay
title: Smart hub is severely lacking
content: The smart hub only works with Alexa, and does not work with other services like IFTTT. For example, you can't use IFTTT to turn on a light connected to the echo plus hub. A regular echo with a separate zigbee hub would be better value for your money. Also, there doesn't seem to be any support for this device (I've never gotten a response from supper). Speaker is ok but not great. There stars is generous.

Problem is with using the HUE lighting system with it.  If you attempt to use it with the HUE bulbs, it works, build disconnects you from being able to manually use with the HUE or Home Kits apps.  Amazon brags on how if the power is shut off it retains whatever info was programmed in pertaining to the lights.  Problem is if you want to remove any lights.  It only lets you disable them from system, but it still retains the info.  So if you reuse the bulb in another area, it shows it twice and so on.  You can't just clear everything from memory and start over.

title: Good Ol' Alexa
content:
This thing works great I was a little disappointed in the speaker, although I think that has more to do with the acoustics of the house and not the speaker its self but thats not why I took a star away. I took a star away because it is so sensitive to hearing its name its kind of annoying, especially when you are listening to music or a book and she interrupts to ask you what you meant. Seriously if a word on the song sounds remotely like her name she interrupts. If your talking on the phone through her and mention amazon she asks me what I want to buy.

I also wish there was a way to put a lock/ keyword/ phrase on her so my kids can't ask her to order more cookies and other random things. I know I could turn that feature off but I like the convience of it. I have a tap, 2 dots, and the echo so its not annoying enough to stop me, but still.

author: ljanelle
title: Great Sound, Good Size, Perfect Purchase
content:
This is the purchase I have been the most excited about in a long time. I bought it on Prime Day, so it was cheaper than normal (and they also threw in a Philips Hue white smart bulb, which made this a very reasonably priced purchase). The Echo is super easy to set up because it walks you through everything using both the Alexa voice assistant and the Alexa phone app.

The sound on the speakers is great. It's obviously not the highest quality sound you can get out of a speaker, but for casual music listeners, this is pretty top-notch (and it destroys the Dot in sound quality). It's also the perfect size for sitting on my kitchen counter without being in the way. I'm most impressed by the microphone range - I have a 1500 sq ft house, and the Echo Plus can hear me almost everywhere (although it seems to be better at recognizing Alexa at long distances than it is at then handling whatever request I lob at it).

The biggest benefit to getting the Plus instead of the regular Echo is that the Plus comes with a ZigBee smart hub built in, so I'm able to control my smart lights without having a separate device. I've gone the Philips Hue route, and I do want to eventually get a Philips Hue bridge because the smart home functions and light colors are kind of limited with just the Plus. However, I can still do a lot of things with my lights using the Plus, like setting up routines for things to happen based on a voice-activation word that I choose (and if you don't make your lights turn on by saying "Lumos", you're missing out - it's Hogwarts all day every day at my house now!).

author: Jane
title: LOVE IT! I consider myself a moderately experienced audiophile ...
content: Have used an Echo Dot, Echo (1st Generation) and now this one. LOVE IT! I consider myself a moderately experienced audiophile with nice home audio equipment (think home audio specialty store quality, not big box stuff) and discerning ear. Clearly, this will not replace Any of those but for a stand alone speaker in it's price range I don't think you will be disappointed. It does not quite have the encompassing bass presence that Bose portable speakers have, (I own one) it is more of a flat response - which is my preference anyway. And, it is not as robust as the Sonos, but it is much cheaper and from other reviews I understand the Alexa/Echo functionality is MUCH more dependable. This set-up combined with Amazon music library has us delighted and even our two year granddaughter is calling for Alexa to play her favorite songs!

Pretty much everyone makes fun of me for spending money on this when I had an awesome Bose bluetooth already. I bought her because my mother (who lives alone) uses hers a lot and is happy with it, but we have a full house with kids and I'm less than impressed. I'd never recommend it to anyone except for senior citizens who love alone and need to be able to shout out for help in the event of a fall.

author: scot m
title: Smart plugs don’t work w Echo plus unless you ad a glitchy 3rd party app to your phone
content: Whats the point of buying the echo plus with built in hub if you have use glitchy 3rd party apps with it. I should not have to use glitchy KASA to control smart plugs bc the echo plus hub and app should just discover and run them. Sadly these TP-Link plugs DO NOT WORK with Alexa. You CANNOT just plug them in turn them on and have Alexa+ discover and seamlessly integrate them into your Alexa smart home. You need to download install a 3rd party app for Which you must register to have and use to set up and Alexa then tries to inter face with the Very glitchy and unreliable KASA app interface. I recommend NOT buying this product unless Amazon fixes the Alexa plus hub software so that it interfaces directly with the smart plug with no glitchy 3rd party hub or app needed. I can also say Alexa + won’t control Philips HUE bulbs without the Philips hub and 3rd party app either.  Very disappointed with echo plus. Does not work as advertised. The 3 tplink plugs I bought don’t work on it bc the KASA 3rd party app I should NOT need to use locks up frequently.

author: Krisztina Rand
title: Stopped working after less than 2 months!
content: The product stopped working after less than 2 months. The connectivity was completely lost and no matter how many times I reset it and how many hours I spent on the phone and on hold with Customer Service, nothing helped. I sent in the device hoping to get it repaired and they sent it back a week later without the power adapter. I was put on hold for another hour with customer service just to get the adapter sent. I will try Google and Apple`s products which are sure to be more reliable. During the first month, I enjoyed the sound and the news briefs from the product but was underwhelmed by the functionality. I have an audible account under a different account and was unable to control more than one account using Alexa. Also, if you have multiple music accounts linked, it seems to randomly select the account and device it connects to.

content: I like Echo, but I really hope there is far more integration and development planned. Because I'm VERY new to this, MAYBE some of these features are already built in, and I have not found a way to those features, but being able to see what is available to watch on my fios TV based on my location and past TV preferences would be nice, being able to add to my amazon wish list via echo and have echo read out a list content would also be nice. Less strict wording of common commands needs to be added.. ie: I like sitting in the den with "colorloop" running on my colored HUE bulbs. Generally it takes me 4-5 tries to get "colorloop" running via echo. I go through this every night. I thought Alexa got smarter as time went on. Being able to set a reminder or timer to other or ALL  devices or dots would be nice so I can move around the house and still get reminded. There is more, but I'm looking forward to seeing how Echo develops.

author: John Sawyer
title: Alexa is an excellent tool for listening to music
content: Alexa is an excellent tool for listening to music, better yet by paying an additional $3.99 per month for a subscription to Amazon Music Unlimited. Alexa voice recognition has much room for improvement. We have not yet used it to initiate orders from Amazon, but suspect it may be error prone until the voice recognition is improved. Echo interfaces with products from other manufacturers, such as Phillips lights, is not user friendly, instructions are not clear, Alexa is fun to use for chats, useful for quick queries on some subjects such as "when do the Celtics (or Bruins or Patriots) next play?" AI learning by Alexa seems to be slow, if at all, but with patience should be expected to provide evolving improvements.

author: Kathleen Dunn
title: Alexa is limited!
content:
Amazon sells the idea of a seemless integration between rooms when using more than one Alexa. But I read you are left with two individual systems that work together for a couple things. You can’t use audiable, Spotify and a few other to stream across both devises at the same time. For the most part it is a speaker that can tell you the weather. “Hey Siri, what’s the weather today?”

Another thing is the comands are sometime cumbersome. Why not have the speakers link and work as on fully interested system? Why not have the option for setting up the fuctionality of how you want the Alexas to interact, like have it programable to play across the platform? And nothing drives me more crazy that when I am talking about Alexa and it chimes in. I now have to keep my conversation about this annoying thing I invited into my house quiet or take it outside.

author: MariMor
title: A rather sad disappointment
content:
I had been the last holdout of all of my friends when it came to purchasing an Echo because I didn't feel its functionality was initially worth it, after all I have a spotify account that connects to wireless speakers, my friends' echos always understand the men better than the women so why have something that doesn't understand me, etc. However, I'd been planning to purchase a philips hue system and when the alexa plus came out, the advertisement that a bridge isn't needed finally made it worthwhile.

However, my impression since receiving this in July 2018 and finally setting it up a month or so later: she's a disappointment. The speakers of this 1st generation echo plus are WORSE than the original Echo. She still doesn't always understand me. She loses connectivity to the dot half the time. And then there is the final and biggest disappointment: I STILL have to purchase a Hue bridge because while you can turn the lights on/off, you can't access the color wheel or create scenes through the Plus.

I suppose I should have been more cynical about what Amazon said and checked with Philips that the Plus really did replace a bridge vs just taking on a functionality I could easily set up with the existing app. Sadly, I was out of the return window by the time I tried it out and since Amazon upgraded the device, I imagine they won't let me replace it in case i just received a lemon with lower grade speakers.

title: Works Well
content:
I ordered the echo plus to go along with the original echo.  I decided upon the plus because I use a lot of Philips Hue lights in the home and thought it would be convenient to have the hub.  This works just like the original echo, but with better sound and it quickly and easily discovers your devices.

After setting it up, however, I began to have a ton of problems with my lights/groups not working, etc.  After contacting customer service, I was told that I should have gotten the Echo Second generation because the plus can not work with the Phillips Hue Hub (which I still wanted to use since it has more features than the echo plus hub).  I also had a list of lights in the Alexa App that I disabled, but could not "forget" within the app and it showed I had over 200 lights connected..which I did not (very frustrating and it became a big mess).

During all of this, I was contacted by another rep who had a higher level of understanding of how the Echo Plus works. In short, you CAN use this with the Phillips Hue Hub, you just can't connect your lights to both hubs.  The error was in my set up; not the device itself.  The representative walked me through the set up process again and also told me about the web based version of the original Alexa app, which allowed me to forget the 200 disabled lights in my app (just Google Alexa Web App)!

In the end, the product is great. It easily connects, has great sound, and you can also connect your phone via bluetooth to play music or podcasts.  I am going to exchange it for the second generation, however, because it will save money as I do not want to use the hub.

author: Jim
title: Watch your “Profile” During Setup
content:
This is my first foray into the Amazon ecosystem.  I wanted to get my feet wet with some smart home capabilities and was interested in using the Echo Plus as a hub. This device can be really easy to setup BUT it may drive you crazy first. I ordered the device on my account and it came registered to my account and Amazon profile. My wife is the official Prime member.  During the initial setup process the Echo switched to her profile unknowingly to me. Thus, as I added smart devices to the Alexa app and was able to control the via the app, Alexa via voice control through the Echo Plus could not discover any new devices.  I called Amazon for help after several hours troubleshooting myself.  The support person was useless going through a script trying things I had already done such as rebooting.  I gave up with this person and worked several more hours on my own.  The next day I was ready to send the Echo Plus back but first I thought I would call Amazon support and try again.

This time the support person was much better. We worked for about 30 minutes before discovering by accident that the Echo was not set to my profile!  Thus, here is the warning, the Echo Plus has user profiles and you must be using the same profile in use on Echo Plus and your Alexa app! Duh!  Just ask Alexa, who’s profile or account is this?  Then the setup was extremely easy.

I have read reviews complaining about the sound.  However, I have been very pleased with the quality of the sound.  It not a sound system bout for one speaker it does a great job.

In terms of controlling smart devices, Alexa works very well and is integrated with many of the devices I already had in use.  My biggest problem is remembering what each light is named.

Finally, the Amazon profiles are problematic.  My wife and I have to continually switch back and forth between profiles to listen to music or control devices.  Yes, we have set up a family profile but that doesn’t resolve this issue of using a specific profile for a particular purpose.

author: Beth
title: Cannot reprogram Alexa so easily.
content: Alexa is pretty cool, but not as efficient as we'd hoped. For instance, she says she cannot find our Fire TV stick or any other devices. But if I ask her to play a certain movie it will appear on our TV. Apparently she is able to connect with TV. Also, Alexa is stuck in Mountain time, but we are in CST. Originally she would report the correct time, but somewhere she switched to MST which is annoying. We have tried reprogramming her from all of her/our apps. The Alexa app says she is now reprogrammed to CST zone, but gives the wrong time when we ask for the time. These two items are frustrating and annoying for us.

author: Amazon Customer
title: but I can say without hesitation that the Echo Plus has pleased me. One hint
content:
I wasn't raised in the computer world--which is a polite way of saying I'm old--and after buying the system and leaving the store, I had some doubts about setting it all up.  At home, my doubts quickly disappeared.  It took ten minutes.  The speaker has clarity enough for anyone who loves music, from jazz and blues to swing and rock.  In the weeks since I've befriended Alexa, she has become my buddy.  She gives me weather in the morning and an eclectic collection of music during the day and evening, along with some interesting facts of the day.  I'm usually hard to please, but I can say without hesitation that the Echo Plus has pleased me.  One hint:  just don't mention Alexa's name within about five yards of the system unless you want to see her circle of light appear, as the lady waits for your request.
Bruns

author: SundayAtDusk
title: Deregister Your Device If It Won't Connect To The Internet . . . .
content:
This is the second Echo Plus I've bought in a month for my elder mother.  I thought she would like an Echo that could control a lamp, and her Echo Dot sometimes doesn't hear her questions, which are usually about the time and weather. :) The first Echo Plus upstairs was easy to connect to the internet, and it controlled the included Philips smart bulb from the start.  With the second Plus downstairs, the message on the Alexa app on my Fire HD8 was always that there was no internet connection.  There was ALWAYS an internet connection, and I was even in the same room with the router and modem when trying to connect.  Not only that but it disconnected both my Fire and the first Echo Plus from the internet!  It happened every time I tried to connect it.  I turned off everything and tried again and again.

The problem seems to be that the Echo Plus creates a sub network called Amazon XXX, and when you choose that network, it doesn't immediately take you to a page where you type in your network security password.  It took me a bit to get to a password sign-in page with the first Plus, but it was impossible with the second one.  It just went to a page saying there was no internet connection with a retry button.  Hitting the retry button repeatedly did nothing, and there was no escaping that page, without turning off my Fire and the Echo Plus and starting the set-up all over again.

In the past, I would have called support; but, to tell you the truth, after years and years of having to call tech reps about things, I don't have the patience any longer for tech support.  Now if something doesn't work, it's going back.  I was going to send the Philips bulb back, too, that came with the Echo Plus as a package deal, but Amazon wanted $5.99 for shipping.  Why? It was part of a package deal.  Moreover, it was shipped in a padded envelope, instead of a box, so I feared it might be defective or compromised.  The bulb box was crushed a bit, as I told Amazon in the return process, but they still thought I should pay to send it back.  Oh well, I'm keeping it.  My mother was not a bit concerned, either, about not having another Echo to control a lamp downstairs, as she had upstairs.  It turns out she turns the upstairs lamp on and off herself without asking Alexa to do so,  just like she has always done her whole long life. :)  If the Echo is still on sale, maybe I'll get that for downstairs, since the Dot does not always hear requests, and the Echo would probably connect like a Dot since it has no built-in Philips hub. Hopefully.

Update 8/29/18:  I got the Echo and had the same exact problem connecting to the internet!  The Alexa app simply wouldn't go to a sign-in page for the network security password, and that kept it off the internet.  Since it came registered, as all Echo devices do if you don't check the gift box when ordering, I wondered if deregistering it would make it go to the sign-in page.  Thus, I did just that either on the Fire, or on my laptop on the "contents and devices" page of my account, I can't remember which. Voila!  As soon as I deregistered the Echo, it went to the sign-in page for my network password and instantly connected to the internet.  Interestingly, I was not asked to register it after that. It did it automatically.

content: Works great I bought this Direct from amazon, and I have got to tell you, This item Echo Show and Echo Plus is the best item I have ever had and I am kind of a tech geek. I am a disabled person, and it helps me turn light on and off, and schedule doctor appointments, using google voice phone, and get my medical rides to and from hospitals, plays music on cue from multiple web apps, and watch videos, as well as communicating to my Nurses aide my schedule and calendar of events. I wish there were programs that helped disabled people get these and smart lights. They are literally the best items since chocolate to assist the disabled and literally anybody else who need them. Although the echo show is not a hub once you set up the Echo plus hub with your lights you can use any amazon device to shut the lights off. Thank God, no more working my ass off to turn on or off lights. Thank you Amazon. I will save up enough money to buy more gift cards from Affirm.com to purchase 1 more of each and some lights for rest of the house. Jeff Bezos these are awesome items and because of your allowing me to get amazon prime at a lower cost due to disability I was finally able to buy these items on your prime day event. really helped when all you earn a month is $672 on SSDI thank you all again.

title: It's Alexa, of course it's awesome.
content: Get this in white. I bought it for my girlfriend in white and I wish I had it in white now. Alexa is one of those devices you will always use and miss when it's not around. I find new uses for Alexa every day. I've Incorporated this device into so many parts of my daily life. As Alexa learns more I learn more. She's my alarm clock, she reminds me of important dates. I'm constantly asking her for information like travel, entertainment, science, history, politics Etc. She turns on and off lights, she's the core of my smart home.

author: Ralph
title: Google Home Mini is better
content: I'm very disappointed with this product. I bought multiple because I wanted to be able to hear my reminders in any room I was in. For some reason Amazon has decided we would not want to hear a reminder if we were in a different room then. Echo we place the reminder on.  Also I bought it for the timers which I thought would be great to help me do work, but you can't pause these or resume them. This means you have to go into the apps Justice if you didn't have the echo. They seem to think this is sufficient because why wouldn't a person want to go into the app I would have to? I would have to ask why would I have the echo if I wanted to go into the app? It's just not really set up to be used the way I'd like to use it.  I need reminders to take my medicine regardless of what room I'm in.  As well as set, pause and resume timers from anywhere. I don't know if Google's is better, but suggest people check it out first.

We got this mainly for our son who is currently vision impaired ! it has many good things and setup was fairly easy once I did the first one but they should be easier to setup and come loaded with more stuff ! it should do Text messages to friends easier without them having to download something for it to work and it should link with email and also them common social media like facebook and twitter and others !
the whole purpose was to get him back connected to the Web by voice so he wouldn't feel left out and isolated ! they should also have a tech support phone number to call or a way to do direct help to the Echo so tech support can help setup the device ! I had to get a friend whos an IT guy to come help me setup

Second, I don't like to ask Alexa to ask another system to do something, such as Alexa ask Bose to play station one etc. It would be nice to say Alexa play music on Bose or whatever system you have.  Third, it would be nice if it can be customized to a specific number of voices only.  Thank God Alexa is a machine or my four year old would have had it pull all its hair out and run naked across the highway.  It is a non stop Alexa do this or Alexa do that. author: Kindle Customer
title: ...frustrated with my Alexa devices because they will only do what I ask them to do about 40%  of the time
content: After a 3 month honeymoon, I am disappointed in my Echo devices because they are not as easy to use or exciting as marketed. I get so frustrated with my Alexa devices because they will only do what I ask them to do about 40%  of the time! Those cute little TV ads that give cute little nonchalant commands to Alexa are so misleading as the devices do not work like that in the real world!  Unless you know exactly what to say to make a Skill work...Alexa will not find the skill or recognize your command...or worse, she will ignore you!  And yes, Alexa even plays a specific sound to tell you she is ignoring you!  I have spent countless hours researching and working with the devices to improve their learning curve but find it too frustrating and time-consuming to figure out what the Echo wants to hear to function properly! I have resorted to writing down and memorizing the exact statements they want to hear in order to get my devices to actually do what I want them to do.  Right now I have a 6-page list laying beside the device reminding me what I have to say to make each skill work on Echo!  On the positive side, I have really enjoyed having the Smart Home devices that Echo pairs with....my Smart Plugs and Sensi Thermostat. Having Alexa turn on my upstairs lights before I get upstairs, make coffee for me before I go to the Kitchen, and turn my Thermostat up to warm my house while I am still in bed has been wonderful!  I also love the Alexa  My Buddy Skill that allows you to set up 5 friends and family members that the skill will alert if you have an emergency at your home and can't reach your phone. It will email, text and call those on your list and alert them to check on you. Although I am disappointed and frustrated with my Echo Plus and Dot most of the time..... I do love the convenience and peace of mind the Smart Home devices (paired with them ) have brought into my life!

title: Fails to properly interface with switch type  Insteon controllers
content:
I ordered the unit to allow voice control of the many Insteon smart home devices in my home. Insteon was listed in the setup as a usable product.  When I initiated the insteon app, the app found multiple devices. Example, I have a device in my living room controlled by a Insteon switch controller. the app offered me 5 icons for this device.  None of them worked!  My light controllers showed up with multiple icons also.trying each of them in most cases I could find one that worked.

At this point I asked for phone assistance.  After almost an hour of trying this n that, I was told that elexa was not designed to work with the Insteon switch controllers.  I told him that lacking the ability to operate all my devices I had no reason to keep the device. He more of less agreed.

A few mins later I received an email a review of our conversation.  Included in the email was a site that would list usable devices.  I went to the list and found an Insteon switch controller.  I sent him a copy of this.

author: hickamcasa
title: Speaker and Hub Very Good...Alexa App Interface Terrible
content:
I’ve had this product for over a month now.  As speakers go the Echo Plus is fine, if your looking for good sounding background music.  If you want/prefer or need a bigger booming sound you need to look at the Sonos One or consider connecting a separate powered speaker to an Echo Dot (while the Echo Plus does have an aux out jack, using the Dot with an external speaker is more economical). I also have a first Gen Echo so utilizing the new multi-room play capability to play the same music in different rooms is a nice feature.  The sound from Gen 1 Echo and Echo Plus is slightly different but not enough to get excited about and/or say that one is better than the other.  Like I indicted above if your looking for dance hall sound look elsewhere.  One thing you should understand is multi-room streaming does not apply to Bluetooth or your own music (since Amazon is discontinuing the ability to up load your own music to Prime Music).  Multi-room is limited to Prime Music and services like Pandora and Spotify.

I selected the Echo Plus over the Gen 2 Echo because of it’s built in Zigbee Hub. I had a few home automation requirements (mostly lighting) I thought the Plus could handle.  I didn’t want or need a Hub to handle thermostats, security, locks, scene lighting, etc, etc.  And I didn’t want to deal with yet “another” App on my iPhone to handle a Wink, SmartThings or Hue hub. Currently, I have two GE Zigbee wall switch dimmers and two Philips Hue smart bulbs connected to the Alexa Plus.  All paired without a problem and all are following the on/off and dimming routines setup in the Alexa App. Those comfortable working with simple electrical DIY will find the GE wired dimmers easy to install (they do however require a connection to the white neutral wire, which may not be available in some older homes). One oddity associated with the Philips smart bulbs is they “pop” on at 100% brightness after a power outage once power is restored.  This does not happen with the GE dimmers.

The biggest issue I have with the Echo Plus is the Alexa App.  The Alexa App “routines” interface is woefully simple and in dire need of improvement. It’s impossible to keep track of, or group, the various times and brightness levels associated with each smart device. I can’t imagine how confusing it would be with a whole house full of smart switches and smart bulbs. It also lacks a dusk to dawn option. The App is so bad I’m reconsidering my resistance to having yet another App on my phone, to interface with a either a Wink or SmartThings hub. From what I’ve read their Apps are more advanced and robust when dealing with smarthome devices. At this point, I’ll give Amazon some time to update the Alexa App.  If that doesn’t happen in the next few months, I’ll begin looking for a different hub.  Todate, all the smart stuff I’ve installed will work with either Wink or SmartThings.  If I switch, I’ll simply relegate the Echo Plus to a speaker only function.

author: MELVYN K BRAY
title: such as acting like a timer for a light to turn on and ...
content: I wasn't aware that it would interfere with my wifi and many additional units would count individually against the wifi max units. I was surprised to learn that I didn't need another hub to operate white lights, e.g. hue from Phillips. Speaking in the words Alexa understands is sometimes problematic as she does not respond as expected. I am still learning how to coordinate functions with Alexa. A simple task, such as acting like a timer for a light to turn on and off is far more difficult than I was prepared for and as of now still not accomplished because there are no examples to follow for that setup. Using it as a countdown timer works very well. Addons will come slower than I anticipated now. I also was not aware that Alexa only updates its information yearly while others update much more frequently.

author: Tracy White
title: When the second generation became available for preorder I did so in anticipation of much better sound and the ability to simplify smart home use
content:
I have owned a first generation echo since it was available for preorder back in the day.  It was satisfactory but the sound was always an issue, being less than robust.  When the second generation became available for preorder I did so in anticipation of much better sound and the ability to simplify smart home use.  The device has proved to be a complete failure in my opinion.  Amazon totally dropped the ball in improving the sound from the speaker, if anything it is inferior to the first generation.  And as for pairing devices that it touts as being compatible with Alexa, Good luck.  They couldn't have made the process for pairing most of the devices, especially the one's offered in "deals" for  the holidays any more difficult or cumbersome.  I had ordered several more to give as gifts, but as a result of the inferior performance of most of the devices I have returned them all and I will disconnect the one I got for myself and return it also.
I'm a loyal shopper and longtime prime member and supporter of Amazon's business model.  This latest release has done quite q bit of damage to that relationship.

author: Brittany Hammond
title: I have been hesitant to purchase anything smart home because I am just not good with electronics
content: I have been hesitant to purchase anything smart home because I am just not good with electronics.  However this surprised me how easy it is to set up and it links to the Bluetooth in my sound bar for my TV which provides extra sound for music, I can make calls and finally hear people when home. I do not have cable, only the paid apps like Netflix and Hulu so when Alexa provided me news stations, weather and other updates it was really great to hear! I have linked all of my accounts to her, she turns on my lights before I walk through the door. She purchases re-orders off of Amazon for my pets and I heard if something bad happened at your home she would place a call to 911 regardless if she was unplugged or not.  This is important as an extra layer of protection for someone living alone.  My tech savvy bf went out and bought her after a week of me having her. Must buy!!!

author: Tina Jones
title: Is anyone else having this same issue with the Plus???
content:
**Follow-up on previous post**  I love my Echo Plus!! Amazon is so great. They are always so helpful and willing to work with me. No issues at all with my new device. I'm disabled and living on very limited funds. I received Alexa as a gift and was very worried that I didn't have the money to replace her. Thank you Amazon :-)
This is my 2nd device...actually 3rd. I was visiting my sister out of state and left my Echo by mistake. But she loved it so much I let her keep it and ordered me the new Plus. M I S T A K E !!!  Keeping this short... every time...after listening  music,  I ask Alexa to play something else like Ambient sounds (Windy Leaves is my fav) or the fan because I it helps me sleep at night.... but it would go back to playing music. I have to unplug device to get it to stop playing music. I exchanged the first Plus device thinking it was just a defective device but it keeps happening with the new one as well. I will update this along with my rating after I contact tech support.... again. BTW.... my first Echo was wonderful!!!! I loved it.

author: LasVegasReader
title: Underwhelmed
content: I wanted another Echo with built in speaker because one of my Echo dots has trouble maintaining a connection with Amazon's own Bluetooth speaker. I like the volume ring (the new regular Echo does not have it),  so I decided to try the new Echo Plus with built in Zigbee hub and a bonus Phillips Hue bulb. I thought it might be nice to experiment with home automation,  for basically the same price as I paid for my original Echo. The result is underwhelming.  Setup was extremely easy.  The new Echo sounds just like the old one. But not discernably better.  I can indeed control the Phillips bulb with Alexa.  However,  this control is limited to "on", "off", and dimming.  This is fun for a minute.  then you realize that the bulb can ONLY be controlled by voice or app. If it is turned off by switch, it's off until switched on again by hand. I realized that I'll rarely if ever use it. Also, I had expected a more robust set of controls,  like timers that would work just like Alexa 's alarms ("Alexa,  turn on my bedside lamp every weekday at 7am"). It seems natural. But alas, no. The new Echo is fine,  but i realize now that I'm not really into voice control.  If i could do more with true automation and the app, i might be back for more.

author: Bruce Meyer
title: Extremely useful and helpful in many ways!
content:
So far the Echo Plus is an awesome addition to my home. The skills (apps) you can enable make Alexa extremely useful for a variety of things that include but are not limited to: Smart home control (lights, light switches, power outlets, locks, etc), reminders, making appointments, shopping lists, voice messaging friends with an Echo, making calls, playing games, finding movies, finding my phone, help with cooking, help with pets, the news, my commute to work, jokes, meditation, music, setting an ambient atmosphere with lights and music, etc, etc, etc.
The list goes on and Alexa's skills are growing, plus you can use the Alexa Blueprints app to create your own skills/apps for your personal use.

author: Fabio Danylo Romano
title: Nice talking to YA!
content:
Now I'm playing!
Finally got to work with our new Echo+... Here's my point:
√The good: Works with a myriad of good products; Hue lights, smart plugs, on/off switches, etc... She can hear && understand you so far away (even outside home); Funny to play with family!
√The bad: No additional languages (Brazilian Portuguese plz); App should be international (intl apple store?); Hard crank machine - it took me so many hours to fine tunning alexa.amazon.com settings (sorry - had too much dirty talking on her!).
Well, after hours of leaning finnaly tunned my preferences - now I love chatting with her! Have some other echo dot and other hub (radio frequency && infra-red) to a complete nice house (errr... should I call our now smart home?).
Best,
.:aeronavilles:.

author: Cantrip
title: I Love my gen 1 Alexa
content:
It is 11-06-2017. I Love my gen 1 Alexa. I have been using it every day since release.  I have an Alexa gen1 & gen 2 in a group. One in each living room downstairs.  My Alexa is playing in groups without me telling it the group name.  it won't play on a single echo, it just defaults to group play. I have to unplug the echo plus to rest it. Then it works fine for a short while. Then it just starts defaulting to group play. Very frustrating.  I hope they fix all these bugs because I love my Alexa. I use it every day, primarily for music. I just want to be able to use group when I say the group name. Once I activate the group name it won't ungroup unless I unplug it to reset it. Echo Gen 1 gets 5 stars. I'm holding out hope for the Echo Plus.
UPDATE:11-8-2017
Alexa plus won't play spotify. I tell Alexa plus to play spotify.  Alexa plus says playing spotify and nothing happens.  I Walk into the the other Room and tell Alexa 1st Gen to play spotify and spotify starts playing.  This is consistently happening. Please Amazon fix these bugs.  This Eco plus is consistently giving me problems whereas the 1st generation Alexa doesn't give me problems at all.

author: David Blanco
title: I'm in the process of upgrading my home into a smart home. For the same price as some hub's
content: I purchased the Amazon Echo Plus on Amazon prime day because I need a hub. I'm in the process of upgrading my home into a smart home. For the same price as some hub's, and even less expensive in some other cases. I got a hub that works with my devices, plus it does a lot more. I haven't even had time to go through all the skills it has, but I've already found myself using many of them. When I started a search for a hub. I wasn't even considering the Echo. In part, because I didn't know it was a hub. But also because I didn't really think I would find much use for another AI system. If you're looking for a hub. Why settle for a plane hub, when you can get a personal assistant that does so much more and yet cost's the same or less than other hubs? Oh! And by the way. For the same price as the Amazon Echo Plus alone. I found one that came bundled with a smart bulb & saw another that came with a smart plug. Given the price of these extras. Well, that just put the Echo Plus over the top.

author: Jugan
title: I will be returning
content:
I am a long time user of Echo and eagerly awaited the successors. The Echo Plus is no such thing.

Please note that many high star reviews are first time echo owners and they don't have the original good unit to compare too. If you are too and reading this, buy the original Echo for around 80$ (not the second gen). If you are a previous echo owner, don't "upgrade".

First and foremost, the sound. Despite being touted as having updated speakers and Dolby, it sounds much worse. Volume does not get as high, bass is always too low, and just sounds muffled. If you have a Dot, then it is comparable to sound quality but just louder. My wife asked what was wrong with it (she didn't know it was the Plus). That was one of the main reasons I got the new Echo, an upgrade to the sound.

The speech recognition is about the same. Maybe bit better but I think that's because this Echo does not get as loud and not as much bass interference as the old one.

Connecting smart devices is about as painful as before, just in a new way. It does basic commands and for basic devices. Very limited. You are better off with a hidden, more powerful hub.

Other than that, it looks almost exactly the same as old Echo, and does same things. Connecting my phone via bluetooth was useless. The new power plug in port is not hidden like the original and cord comes out easily.

Overall, I am going to return it. 150$ for a downgrade. It's a shame.

author: Bobbi Halvorsen
title: Frustrated and agitated!
content:
I have been thinking about getting this for a long time and was excited when it arrived bundled with a Philip Hue bulb.  The excited ended quickly.  I spend about a total of 4 hours attempting to add this bulb to my Alexa Echo Plus.  Everything I tried, ended in a Discovery Failed message.  I tried to set this up over and over and over again.  I watched YouTube videos.  I read set up websites.  I was the poster child of insanity (doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results).

The next day I went onto Amazon to get the tech support.  I was hoping something would be done to make this thing work, but also the problem not being operator error.  Well after 3 tech support staff and 1 hr. and 19 mins. of being on the phone, it still didn't work.  This product has tested my patience.  So far this experience is shifting my mindset from going to a smart home to just kicking it old school.

The only reason I gave this two stars is because Amazon will be sending me a different Echo Plus and light bulb.  The problem wasn't the bulb, because before packing up the items, I purchased another bulb and still Alexa couldn't locate this device.

I pray the next attempt is successful and then I will revise this rating, but what are the odds that I was shipped a defective Echo?  The support person had the same thought.  Maybe I should be exploring the Google device but I can't get over the look of that hub.  It looks like a defuser.

I can't believe I didn't find YouTube videos that show the problems I did.  Everything looked simple and seamless...NOT the experience I had.  OK, I'm done with this review because I spend enough wasted time this weekend already.

author: Morgan Cassady
title: New and Improved? No! What happened?????????
content:
I am very frustrated with this new device. I have several older versions of the device in my house and they work brilliantly and I love them.

So far, I have been very disappointed with the new model. On the new model, it has struggled with basic commands that the old model has no problems running. At first, I thought I got a defective model so I returned it and got a new one shipped to me. The new one arrived and it has the same learning disabilities. It just doesn't work. I have to disable a skill and then re-enable the skill to work. I have to do this every day. I have followed the steps provided by support but it still fails.

I run the ambient noise app at night for sleep sounds, it always turns off after 1 hour even after setting a longer sleep timer or even when I tell the Alexa to turn the loop on. The Loop on should run until I tell Alexa to stop. She acknowledges the command and says she will remember it for next time. NOPE. She fails. At this moment, I would recommend buying the previous model refurbished.

I keep finding failures in the operation of this device. It is frustrating. So what improvements did Amazon make in the new model? They have taken a fine product and made worse. They took my Ferrari and made it a Honda Civic missing a muffler.

author: Dr. Bear
title: Hooked on Echo Plus, Alexa and listening to endless music... !!
content:
First I want to say that a novice in networking "could" potentially have trouble getting everything set up initially.
If you plug in the Echo Plus and get on a PC at alexa.amazon.com, click Settings, click Set up a New Device and follow the instructions, it should install and connect to your Amazon account.  Be sure to have your WiFi password.
I also got 2 Philips Hue light bulbs to play with. I put one in a hallway lamp and one in a TV room lamp.  Leave the lamps turned on.  Say, "Alexa, discover devices".  She should find them in a few seconds - once discovered, they should show up at  alexa.amazon.com.
Create a group(s) and give the group a name like "hallway", "bedroom", etc. and assign the light bulbs to the group.  You can then say, "Alexa, turn on hallway", or "bedroom".  You could do the same thing with Alexa compatible electrical outlet adapters, with lamps plugged in to them and  you could use standard LED or other light bulbs.
You don't need the Philips or other 3rd party apps to use Alexa controlled devices "inside" the home.  The apps are needed only if you plan to control the devices while outside of the home network.
The Echo Plus has a builtin Smart Home hub that talks to all the Alexa controlled devices.  Without the builtin hub, you would need a 3rd party hub from Philips or other manufacturer.
The Echo Plus has a good bass sound and as far as my ears can tell, rocks out 80's heavy metal just fine !
There are a ton of skills and features I haven't had time to delve in to.  I will grow my Smart Home for sure.
One simple thing to do is say Alexa, " add popcorn to my Shopping List".
Put the Alexa app on your smart phone and you can pull up the Shopping List when out and about without the need for paper and all that.

Enjoy !!

author: Tabitha V Maze
title: Had problems with internet connections but I still love the Echo Plus
content: I love everything about it. I love that the echo plus turns on and off my light. It can also dim them with voice commands. I also like listening to my kindle books even the ones that I didn’t purchased  audibles for. I like that it can play my music from Amazon music, pandora, tunein, I heart radio and Spotify. Echo can even play my local radio station. I love that the echo is connected to my TiVo Bolt. This allows TiVo to pause, stop and play whatever I want with a simple voice command. I love that I can reorder items that I purchased on Amazon and that the echo plus notifies me when my order is mailed, when it will be delivered and when the package has been delivered.  The only three dislikes that I have is that if you’re up too close or to far the echo doesn’t respond. So I think they need to improve the microphone. And I wish the speaker was better. The speakers are okay but could be improved. Also I have the echo dot and it never has given me any problems with the internet. Well the other day I received a Red Light Right on my Echo Plus. This error was Sorry I’m having trouble understanding you please try again later. After research online I learned it was a problem connecting to my internet. And it was easy to find this out. And I found it odd that my dot wasn’t having this problem even though they are connected to the same network.

author: Shane and Veronica Breeden
title: Echo Plus Hue
content: My husband and I have had an Echo for about a year. We have had a Phillips Hue light system for about 4 years. When we went to the Amazon Pop Up at the local mall, we were introduced to the Echo Plus. I love that the Echo Plus pairs so well with my Hue Lights. We can simply tell it to turn off our lights. I love that the speaker gets much louder than the original echo. I can't wait to pair other devices with our Echo Plus.

But if you like listening to the music on loud, you might want to get the remote. The music seams to over power the microphones on the echo.

author: lorraine
title: Alexa
